petition.title: Wynyard Airport, Tasmania
petition.para: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:
Wynyard Airport, Tasmania
To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Tasmania shows:
(a) We are shocked and disappointed at the Federal Government's decision not to upgrade the Wynyard Airport.
(b) This decision will inevitably lead to downgrading and closure of the Wynyard Airport.
(c) Closure of Wynyard Airport will cause grave hardship and inconvenience to the people of the North West and West Coast regions of Tasmania.
(d) We urge the Federal Government to immediately reverse this disastrous decision.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

petition.title: Non-Government School Funding
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That every child in Australia is entitled to government financial support for their education whether they attend government schools or non-government schools .

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that urgent consideration be given to a favourable decision for the continuation of Federal Government per capita grants payable in respect of all children in non-government schools at a rate calculated as a percentage of Government standard costs at a level not less than that prevailing in 1983.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

petition.title: Sex Discrimination Legislation
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
That the Commonwealth Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 could be used to support the provision by the Commonwealth Government of funding, counselling, etc. for deliberately procured abortions.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled:
should amend the Sex Discrimination Bill so as to prevent it from being used in support of deliberately procured abortions.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

petition.title: Education
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition from parents representing the government schools in New South Wales respectfully showeth that:
1. They call on the Federal Government to re-affirm publicly that its primary obligation is to government schools.
2. They support the Federal Government's policy decisions which have reduced funding to wealthy private schools and which have broken the nexus between government and non-government school costs.
3. They endorse the Federal Government's opposition to the provision of a 'base grant' to all non-government schools.
4. They ask that the Federal Government create a general recurrent resource base which is adequate for government schools through the provision of increased recurrent funding.

5. They call upon the Federal Government to negotiate agreements with State- Territory Governments which will ensure a planned program of improvements in government schools throughout the coming decade.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

petition.title: Education
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens, teachers and parents working in and for the interests of the pupils in government schools and colleges throughout Australia respectfully showeth that:

1. We deplore the unprincipled and self-interested attacks being orchestrated by minority sects and groups against the policies and person of the Commonwealth Minister for Education and Youth Affairs, the Hon. Senator Susan Ryan.
2. We fully support the Federal Government's actions in reducing funds for the wealthiest private schools, and in breaking the nexus between government and non -government school costs.

3. We endorse the Federal Government's principled opposition to the provision of 'base grants' to all non-government schools, as a positive step towards fulfilling their commitment of primary obligation to Australia's government schools.

4. We call upon the Federal Government however to recognise that its failure to create an adequate general recurrent resource base for government schools through providing increased recurrent grants, will undermine its own special programs and thus frustrate its own stated educational objectives of greater equity and participation.

5. We support the Federal Government's stated policy of entering into direct negotiations for joint agreements on these grants with State-Territory Governments, to ensure a planned programme of improvements in government schools throughout the coming decade.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

petition.title: Medicare
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
That, with the exception of the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory, all State Parliaments have enacted chiropractic legislation.
That chiropractors provide a safe, effective and economical health care service that is complementary to medicine.

That the introduction of a Federally-funded health care system restricted to the services provided almost exclusively by the medical profession restricts the freedom to select the health care practitioner of one's choice.
That a financial disadvantage will be incurred by those citizens utilising chiropractic care, many of whom find that their health complaints do not respond satisfactorily to traditional approaches.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled ensures that chiropractic services are included in Medicare when it is introduced.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

petition.title: Nuclear Disarmament
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. The concerns which people around the World have for the increasing stockpiles of weapons of mass destruction;
2. The global concern that any nuclear exchange will inflict on humanity unimaginable death and suffering;
3. The vulnerability that Australians will face in any nuclear conflict between the major powers;
4. The public concern that Government should explore all avenues to ensure that the nuclear threat is eliminated.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament establish a Senate Select Committee on Nuclear Disarmament and Peace to investigate the creation of a Ministry of Peace and Nuclear Disarmament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

petition.title: Australian Cadet Corps
petition.para: To the Honourable President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia shows:
That the Australian Cadet Corps has great value in the development of youth in schools of Australia.
That the reorganisation of the Australian Cadet Corps will disperse accumulated expertise and interest of those involved and in some cases, negate the efforts of many people over many years.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the government will reconsider its decision, and that the Government will not reorganise the Australian Cadet Corps .
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

petition.title: Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain elected representatives and officers of local governments in Australia shows that:
General revenue grants to Local Government under personal income tax sharing entitlements have increased by 8.2 per cent in 1983-84 over 1982-83,
The inflation rate over the same period was 11.2 per cent,
The increase in grants to State Governments over the same period was 11.8 per cent,
Increased demands are being made on local government authorities to participate in Federal Government programs e.g. Community Employment Program,
The Labor Party made a pre-election commitment to allocate not less than the real value of the previous year's allocation in general revenue grants to local government.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Government will amend the Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act of 1976, to provide a real term minimum guarantee to local government general revenue sharing arrangements in 1983-84, and in future years.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

proctext.para: Notice of Motion

speech.speaker: Evans Sen J.G.

talk.start.para: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

speech.para: That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act relating to collective agreements regulating the terms and conditions of employment of employees of corporations, and for purposes connected therewith.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Attorney-General in his capacity as representing both the Minister for Defence and the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer to an interview with the Minister for Foreign Affairs this morning in which he said that he had had a telephone conversation with Secretary of State George Shultz who is in Madrid, in relation to the confusion and head of steam which has arisen over the statements by the Minister for Defence, concerning the visit of HMS Invincible, and its implications for visits by allied naval vessels, particularly from the United States. I ask the Attorney- General: Have officers from the United States Embassy concluded the discussions with officials of the Department of Foreign Affairs which Mr Hayden said would be held this morning? Have these talks 'nipped in the bud'-to use Mr Shultz's words-any misunderstanding, confusion or ambiguity which has resulted from the confusing statements by the Minister for Defence in relation to the HMS Invincible visit? What assurances are being sought, have been sought or have been given to the United States at today's talks?

answer.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talk.start.para: —I am advised that the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Hayden, did speak with the United States Secretary of State, Mr George Shultz, by telephone this morning. Mr Shultz was in Lisbon at the time, in transit. Mr Shultz volunteered that there was a need to 'nip in the bud', as Senator Durack said, very quickly any misunderstanding which might have been generated in the public commentary on this matter, especially insofar as that commentary might be related to United States attitudes. In consequence of this discussion, the United States Charge d'Affaires, Mr Lyne, was shortly to have discussions with the Department of Foreign Affairs. I am not clear as to whether those discussions have taken place or are now taking place; they were certainly, as I understand it, to take place very soon.

answer.para: The discussion between Mr Shultz and Mr Hayden was, I am told, extremely cordial. Secretary of State Shultz stressed the strength and the welcome nature of the relationship that existed between Australia and the United States. He particularly expressed his pleasure at the fact that both the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, and the Foreign Minister, Mr Hayden, have established a confident and mutually self-respecting association with United States Administration officials such as himself. Such association allows direct and immediate communication such as that which took place on this occasion to take place on matters of interest to the respective parties to the Australia-United States alliance. It is very apparent from the terms of this exchange this morning that the United States Administration does not share the concern being unjustifiably developed in some quarters about what are the purported as distinct from factual circumstances about HMS Invincible; nor does the United States Administration wish to contribute to that concern.

talk.start.para: —I address my question to the Minister for Resources and Energy . I refer to representations made over recent months by the operators of the Greenvale nickel project in northern Queensland for Commonwealth assistance by way of exemption from the excise on fuel oil used by that project. I ask the Minister: Has the Government considered these representations? Is the Commonwealth able to offer Greenvale any assistance?

answer.speaker: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

talk.start.para: —The Commonwealth has received representations from a number of people, not the least of whom are Senator Reynolds and Mr Lindsay, the member for Herbert, who have both made very strong representations on this question. The Commonwealth has decided to remit the excise. There are two ways in which this can be done: Either by way of a section 96 grant to Queensland to compensate the company for the excise which is paid; or the possible alternative of some by-law type arrangement-I do not want that to be taken too literally- exempting that particular mineral processing plant from the excise on fuel oil. The principal reason the Commonwealth has taken that decision is that fuel oil used in the Greenvale nickel smelter is not just used as a fuel but as a chemical reductant. Exemption from excise of fuel oil used for that purpose is consistent with the arrangements under which petrochemical plants which use fuel oil as chemical feed stock are exempt from the excise. In those circumstances, both the petrochemical plants and the Greenvale nickel smelter, since they are not using fuel oil as a fuel per se, do not have the option of using alternative fuels.

answer.para: The Greenvale plant is unique among mineral processing plants in that the fuel oil is not used as a fuel. As a result of the Commonwealth decision to exempt in one way or another the Greenvale project from excise on fuel oil, at present production levels within that smelter the company will benefit by about $1.5m in a full year. I spoke yesterday to the Queensland Government about this matter, with a request that it consider some type of what could roughly be called matching assistance, given that because of the depressed price of nickel and a number of other factors, this project has been marginal for some time. The Queensland Government collects by way of overt taxes from the project at present levels of production about $140,000 in royalties and $780,000 in payroll tax. I can understand, of course, that the Queensland Government may be reluctant to consider remitting or reducing either of those charges because it would create precedence for extension to other projects. It would be difficult to quarantine a charge of that nature.

However, the rail freights charged by the State railways for the transport of ore do include a profit component which I am advised is probably in the vicinity of $1.5m I believe that the Queensland Government should give very serious consideration to reducing the rail freight currently being charged to that extent, particularly in view of the fact that the 240 kilometre railway was paid for by the company, along with the locomotives and the rolling stock which operate on it, and transferred as a gift to the Queensland State railways on 1 January 1975. I do not know whether the Queensland Government will consider our request seriously. I am somewhat alarmed that, I understand, the Queensland Government had earlier had a proposal to escalate the pure profit component-in other words, a hidden tax-of that rail freight and that that matter is currently before the Supreme Court of Queensland. But the Commonwealth has made its contribution to secure the continued operation of this plant, recognising its importance to the Townsville region. Although we have clearly no control over what the Queensland Government does, we sincerely hope that the Queensland Government will make a similar gesture.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence and Minister for Foreign Affairs. Has the Hawke Government sought, and, if so, will it continue to seek, declarations from allied governments as to whether naval ships visiting Australian ports are carrying nuclear weapons? Did not the Attorney-General concede on Friday that for sound operational reasons our major allies neither confirm nor deny the carriage of nuclear weapons on board their war ships? So what point is there in continuing with this policy? If it is to be pursued, and given the inevitable response, does not this mean that we are likely to witness a repetition of the HMS Invincible fiasco every time a possibly nuclear armed allied warship is in need of Australian docking facilities? Is this a sensible policy to pursue towards our allies?

answer.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talk.start.para: —It is long-standing policy applied by conservative governments as well as Australian Labor Party governments that naval vessels using dry docking facilities in Australia have to disarm. Certain exemptions can be made under specified conditions but that is and has been always the practice. There is no question that Australia could ever allow the safety of the crew of any ship, whether it be naval or merchant marine, to be put at serious risk by refusing to provide assistance for a vessel suffering from some disability that endangers its sea-going capacity. But I understand that was not the situation in this case. To the extent that there is any continuing ambiguity or confusion about these matters and about the preliminary matters thereto, to which Senator Hamer referred-questions in turn being put to the people running those ships which want to dry dock-these matters will be the subject of consultation with our major allies so that there is a clear understanding about how these established practices should apply.

answer.para: I should add, however, that most of this discussion is largely hypothetical and theoretical because the situation remains as I stated in this place last week and as Mr Scholes has stated on several occasions. There has been no question of a refusal or prohibition of entry of the Invincible to dry docking in Australia because no actual request has been made to Australia by the British authorities. It is true that the possibility of dry docking has been canvassed by the British but, in the event, they decided that dry docking would not be required in Sydney for what they described as operational reasons.

talk.start.para: —I ask a supplementary question on the Attorney-General's rather curious reference to the ship being disarmed, which I think is only one example of a very poor brief. On that question I ask him: How much closer to the centre of the city of Sydney would be HMS Invincible if it were in the Captain Cook dry dock rather than alongside Garden Island? What increased dangers would be involved in the ship being in dry dock?

—My brief, for the benefit of Admiral Hamer or anyone else, does not extend to the answer to that particular question but I will seek further particulars from the Minister concerned and let Senator Hamer know.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer and it refers to the Government's decision to float the dollar. Can the Minister indicate the likely impact this decision will have on import competing industries, particularly the motor vehicle and white goods manufacturing industries, both of which I add are crucial to my home State of South Australia? Is there any cause for the alarm being expressed by metal trades industry employers and unions over the possibility of job losses in these import competing industries?

answer.speaker: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

talk.start.para: —If, as a result of the decision to float the Australian dollar, the Australian exchange rate was higher than it otherwise would have been, the answer to Senator Foreman's first question is yes, such a movement would adversely affect not only import competing industries but also exporting industries-in fact probably more so exporting industries. The second question he asked was whether there was any cause for the alarm being expressed by metal trades industry employers and unions and so on at prospective job loss. The answer to that is no, not at this stage. There is no cause for alarm because there is no evidence to suggest that the value of the Australian dollar has gone up as a result of the decision to float it. Indeed, to this stage the evidence suggests that the value of the Australian dollar is, as a result of the decision to float it, lower than it would have been had previous practices been continued .

answer.para: Of course, the background to this is that in March and late February, largely because of grossly irresponsible statements by the present Leader of the Opposition, Mr Peacock, the foreign currency speculators raided the Australian dollar. As a result of that successful raid-I stress 'successful' because it was assisted by the present Leader of the Opposition and without dissent from any member of his party-foreign speculators succeeded in stealing-I do not think that is too strong a word to use-from the citizens of Australian several hundred million dollars because of the devaluation of the exchange which was caused by that run on the dollar. The decision by the present Leader of the Opposition to try to induce a run of the dollar followed, of course, the decision of the discredited former Prime Minister to try to induce a run on the banks. The run on the banks piece of irresponsibility did not succeed but, lamentably, the run on the dollar piece of irresponsibility did. In an inverse way foreign currency speculators have been trying to do the same thing in the last few weeks and have been pouring foreign capital into Australia with the view to forcing a revaluation, an upward movement in the value of the Australian dollar, and then picking up the resultant gains from their anti-social activities.

With a view to putting an end to that attempt yet again to raid and rob the citizens of Australia, the Reserve Bank of Australia tried in several days of last week to get through to foreign speculators the message that their antisocial activities would not be rewarded and it adjusted the exchange rate of the Australian dollar back to 0.9025 vis-a-vis the United States dollar. Of course on Friday, as is well known, it suspended trading in the dollar altogether pending a decision by the Government. That decision was announced by the Treasurer late on Friday afternoon and was a decision to float the dollar. As a consequence there was some movement in the exchange rate yesterday. I am going through these figures quickly but at one stage the Australian/United States dollar ratio peaked at just over 92c but fell to 91.5c towards the end of the day's trading. The latest advice which I have been given is that the rate today was in fact down to 90.25c. That is the level to which the Reserve Bank had depressed it, quite deliberately, last Thursday afternoon. Bearing in mind that that was a conscious decision by the Reserve Bank to try to warn off the foreign speculators, it would seem that, as a result of the floating of the dollar, up to this stage the exchange rate is somewhat lower than it would have been in the absence of that decision.

I give due credit to the present Deputy Leader of the Opposition for supporting the Government's decision made last Friday. It was supported also by a surprisingly diverse group of people-exporters, the National Farmers Federation and miners-and received general support throughout the community. There was some criticism, although qualified criticism, by a respected economic journalist in the Melbourne Age. There was also criticism by Dr Theophanous, on the extraordinary ground that he had not been consulted on the matter, as if it were customary for a Treasurer or a government to consult widely as to whether they were going to change the value of the Australian dollar. I found that criticism rather bizzare. The decision was criticised also by Mr Kevin Parry in Perth. He is a director of Western Mining Corporation Ltd. His basic rule, when commenting on Government policy, seems to be to oppose everything the Labor Government does .

talk.start.para: —Order! The Minister is tending to debate the answer now.

—I am just about to close, Mr President. He was out of step with the mining industry. In general, the Government decision was broadly and well received. The judgment, at least to this stage, has been vindicated.

—My question also is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. I hope his answer is as full and informative as were the answers to his two Australian Labor Party colleagues. Are there three contracts for uranium from Mary Kathleen involving 4,225 short tonnes of yellowcake yet to be fulfilled? As Mary Kathleen mine was closed over a year ago and its plant sold, where is the uranium coming from to fulfil these contracts? Is the answer that the Australian uranium is stockpiled at present at conversion or enrichment plants in Canada or France? Does India have a nuclear bomb today essentially because of Canada? Is nuclear testing in the Pacific taking place because of France? Will the Minister inform me what safeguards apply to these stockpiles outside Australian jurisdiction and tell me how we can be absolutely confident that our yellowcake, totally beyond our control, is not being diverted into nuclear weapons?

—The first question was: Are contracts for some 4,200 short tonnes of yellowcake yet to be fulfilled by Mary Kathleen? I am advised that the answer is no. Approximately 200 tonnes of yellowcake has been committed under contract and is yet to be delivered. I understand that that is currently in enrichment plants or somewhere in the delivery pipeline, probably in Canada and France. That answer deals with the second and third question as well. The fourth question related to India having an atomic device. Of course, as is well known, India does have an atomic device which was exploded in 1974 and which was constructed from plutonium derived from uranium supplied by Canada but, I note importantly, used in a research reactor and not in a power reactor. That is an important distinction because I am advised that--
—Doesn't the bomb that comes from that hurt anybody? Is that why it is different?
—Hear me out. While it is possible to make atomic weapons from fuel rods irradiated in a power reactor, power reactors are not the ideal source of raw materials for atomic weapons.
—Pathetic. It is still a bomb, isn't it?

—Does Senator Chipp want to know the facts? The point I am making is that somebody whose sole ambition was to make a bomb would not go down the power reactor route towards making that bomb. I believe that is an important distinction. Bombs can be made from research reactors, one of which, incidentally operates in Australia, although it is not operated with the intention of producing plutonium to make atomic weapons. The final question that Senator Chipp asked concerned safeguards. I have given a fairly full answer on this before, to the effect that Australian uranium is subject to bilateral nuclear safeguards agreements with all customers which require an input and output balance for Australian uranium going to enrichment plants or reactors. I am advised it is not possible to get a precise balance of what goes in and what goes out; there is always a very small quantity not accounted for. But in addition, as a backup safeguard to the in and out counting, those plants are also subject to inspection by International Atomic Energy Agency inspectors.

—I ask a supplementary question. I say, with respect, that I am disappointed with the answer because the Minister's Department has had that question since last Friday. Do I take it from the Minister's answer that only 200 tonnes of Australian yellowcake is stockpiled overseas, in France and Canada , which is bound for Japan and America to fulfil contracts?

—I am advised by the Department that, yes, 200 tonnes of yellowcake is yet to be delivered and that delivery has actually been made of all the other amounts specified in Mary Kathleen contracts. I have not had a chance to check with the Department today. I saw a note from it-
—But why are we storing it in Canada to sell it to America?

—I am not sure to whom it is ultimately to be delivered. I am advised that the 200 tonnes in question is currently in conversion plants in France and in Canada. I am not aware at this stage of the country to which it is ultimately to be delivered.

question.block.title: DEPARTMENT OF FOREIGN AFFAIRS: MR J. E. RYAN

talk.start.para: —Has the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs seen the allegation in the Bulletin of 13 December that Mr J. E. Ryan, the head of the Australian Secret Intelligence Service, was caught out in falsifying information in a letter to the then Minister for Foreign Affairs, the Hon. Don Willesee? Is this allegation correct and, if so, will Mr Ryan be stood down from his post while matters pertaining to the Sheraton fiasco are investigated in order to prevent any chance of a cover-up?
—I will refer this further allegation in relation to Mr Ryan to the Minister for Foreign Affairs for such answer as he may care to provide.

question.speaker: Townley Sen M.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Attorney-General, representing the Ministers for Defence and Foreign Affairs. I refer the Attorney-General to the following extract of words of the Minister for Defence on the AM program this morning:

question.para: But with regard to the Invincible, the British Government advised us that it would not be taking up the offer of docking in Sydney.
When was the offer made and at what level was it communicated to the Royal Navy? Is the Minister able to advise the Senate just what were the terms and conditions of the offer?

talk.start.para: —I am afraid I have no information before me as to the precise words utilised by Mr Scholes on AM this morning and I am somewhat surprised to hear the suggestion being made that there was some formal offer of dry docking. That is not my understanding of what occurred, but clearly this is another matter on which my brief, undernourished as it is, will need supplementation by some further request to the Minister concerned. I will do my best to get an instant reply.

—Has the Attorney-General seen Press reports that the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, Mr Paul Everingham, has said that despite a letter he received from the Prime Minister on the subject, he intends to introduce the Northern Territory Criminal Code on 1 January 1984? Is there any action which the Attorney can take to protect the people of the Northern Territory from a code which has been described as one of the most regressive, outmoded and unfortunately drafted pieces of legislation in the history of this country?

answer.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talk.start.para: —I have seen reports that Mr Everingham has been less than his usual gracious self in responding to the Prime Minister's reasonable, moderate, constructive and responsible proposals to him in his letter of 17 November with respect to the Code. Indeed, I understand that Mr Everingham's graciousness has not so far extended to the point even of replying to Mr Hawke's letter which Mr Everingham was kind enough, I understand, to describe as a crude piece of electioneering.

answer.para: In fact, it was very far from that. The Prime Minister's letter, which was tabled or incorporated in Hansard by me in an answer a few weeks ago, reflects a very serious concern which many responsible Australians feel about the terms not by any means of the entire Code, but certainly a number of provisions of it, which break innovative ground in establishing new kinds of criminal offence which do so in many respects in ways that have hitherto been thought incompatible with State or Territory law as distinct from Commonwealth law, and which in many other instances produce results which are quite at odds with fundamental principles of criminal justice. I refer in particular to questions about necessary state of mind in offences involving intoxication.

They are serious and important matters which have been raised with Mr Everingham and it is to be hoped that the Northern Territory Chief Minister will take seriously the points that have been made and reply sensibly and constructively to them.

The problem is that the Code comes into force in its present form on 1 January. The Government would certainly prefer that a co-operative approach were adopted to the resolution of this matter, following discussions that have taken place at officer level between someone from my Department and the relevant people in the Northern Territory. Certainly we would prefer that any changes that were to be made to the Code were made within the Northern Territory, rather than by virtue of any exercise by the Commonwealth of its residual constitutional power over the Territory and, in particular, the powers that it possesses under the Northern Territory (Self-Government) Act.

In the event that it becomes apparent that Mr Everingham, when he gets around to replying to Mr Hawke's letter, will not co-operate in any kind of constructive way in trying to remove these sources of very serious concern, it will be necessary for the Government to review its position further on this matter. Until then, I think any further discussion of this whole issue would be premature. We continue, as I say, to nurture the hope that some kind of reason and sanity will prevail and that it will not be necessary for any more extreme action to be taken by the Commonwealth.

question.speaker: Reid Sen M.E.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister representing both the Minister for Defence and the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I draw his attention to an answer by the Minister for Defence in the House of Representatives last week when he said:

question.para: The question of the visit to Sydney by the HMS Invincible has been under active discussion for some considerable time.

When did the discussions begin? At what level were they conducted? At what point in the discussions and for what reasons did the British High Commissioner seek an interview with the Minister for Defence?

talk.start.para: —I have no information on the particular matters to which the honourable senator referred. I will seek it as soon as possible from the Minister for Defence.
—My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. I ask him: Is he satisfied with the operation of the repatriation hospital system at present?

answer.speaker: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

talk.start.para: —I think in a short answer, I would have to say no, I am not satisfied with the repatriation hospital system. I believe that governments in the past have placed too much emphasis on cash benefits for veterans and paid insufficient attention to the maintaining of a separate hospital system comparable with that provided by the States. When I acknowledge that, I do not wish in any way to be derogatory about the administrators of the repatriation general hospital system because I think they have been victims of government policies which have been designed to maintain the hospitals as they were rather than as they should progress.

answer.para: We live in a world today where most of the State hospital systems have had access to specialised equipment and new technology which have kept them abreast of the developments in medicine. That has not occurred at the same rate in our repatriation general hospitals. It is my view, having looked at the hospital system, that the repatriation general hospitals generally could be put in a second rate category rather than in a first rate category in which I believe they should be. I point out that, having regard to the fact that the great bulk of veterans are now in the 60 and 80 age group and, therefore, would be obviously eligible for treatment in such hospitals, it is clear that this Government will have to spend a lot more money on equipment to modernise our repatriation general hospital system. As I have indicated, I do not in any way criticise the dedicated staff who work within our hospital system.

I have been recently advised by the Minister for Finance, Mr Dawkins, that his officers have been looking at representations that I made in respect of the last Budget. Whilst there were very substantial increases in allocations to our hospital system, the Minister's advice to me is that he agrees with the Department of Veterans' Affairs that there does need to be a great deal more work done in the hospital system in the provision of specialised equipment, and that is something that will be attended to in the budget considerations for 1984 -85.

question.speaker: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

talk.start.para: —I again refer the Minister representing the Ministers for Foreign Affairs and Defence to the statement of the Minister for Defence that:

question.para: . . . the British Government advised us that it would not be taking up the offer of docking in Sydney.

My question is in four parts. First, what is the Government's understanding why the captain of HMS Invincible did not accept the offer? Secondly, is there any reason known to the Government why the captain might conclude that the maintenance and repairs of the ship would not be done expertly and speedily and the ship released in reasonable time to continue its journey? Thirdly, did the Government give any assurances to the captain of Invincible that the work would be performed effectively and speedily? If not, why not? Finally and fourthly, alternatively, did the Government or the captain have any reason to believe that this might not be so and that such assurances could not be given?

talk.start.para: —The only answer I am able to give to Senator Sir John Carrick is essentially the answer that I have given previously: That my understanding is that no formal request was made by the British authorities to Australia; that, to the extent that any language was used by the Minister for Defence suggesting that an offer of dry docking facilities was made, I will need to check that further and establish with him whether that is in fact (a) what he said and (b) what he intended to say; and, thirdly, that, to the extent that the question of dry docking was ever canvassed between the British authorities and made the subject of discussion between them and the Australian authorities, the decision by the British authorities, in the event, was that the dry docking would not be required for what were described as operational reasons. Now whether those operational reasons extended to a consideration of the time that would be taken, bearing in mind the non-essential character apparently of the repairs in question so far as ensuring the seaworthiness of the ship is concerned, I do not know. I will have to seek further information.

question.speaker: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

talk.start.para: —Would the Attorney-General, in the light of his last few comments, look at any specific information he could give me on each of the four specific parts of my question and let the Senate know?
—I will, of course, as I always do, communicate the text of the question to the Minister concerned and elicit from him such response as he may be prepared to make.

—My question, which I direct to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, refers to the recent statement by the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Mr Willis, regarding alternative job creation proposals. Can the Minister say what reaction the Government has had to the concept of community co-operatives since it was first mooted by the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, earlier this year? Is the Government giving serious consideration to developing a wider range of options to cope with future unemployment and labour projections?

—I cannot say what response the Government has had to the suggestions made about community co-operatives as at least a partial solution to the unemployment problem. I think I can offer the comment that whatever response there has been has been pretty mute. Nonetheless, that is a matter which, together with a wide range of other matters, is under consideration by the Government. As the honourable senator is aware, the Government has been looking at issues involving part time employment. Various statements have been made by Ministers relating to the length of the working life in Australia. I think it is fair to say that there has been no decision on any of these matters at the moment. However, they constitute a variety of issues which are being canvassed. In due course the Government will reach a decision on those matters and an appropriate announcement will be made. Insofar as the community co-operatives question is concerned, I think many of these issues, particularly that one, will await the outcome of an Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development review of manpower programs as they relate to young people. Those matters will be considered in that context after that report is tabled by the OECD.

question.block.title: RED RU PIPELINE CONSTRUCTIONS PTY LTD

talk.start.para: —Has the attention of the Attorney-General been drawn to the situation surrounding the Jackson oil pipeline and in particular the situation with regard to Red Ru Pipeline Constructions Pty Ltd which started with 100 per cent equity and finished with none after the intervention of the Queensland Government? Has the Government given any consideration to investigating the commercial and political events that have taken place with regard to the exclusion of Red Ru to ascertain whether or not there have been any breaches of Federal laws? Has the Government considered referring the whole affair to the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union?

—I have no knowledge of the matters to which Senator Macklin refers. I hope I am not supposed to have some knowledge. If I am, I will no doubt have an appropriate bit of paper by the end of Question Time. I will just have to take the question on notice at the moment and give the honourable senator a considered response as soon as I possibly can.

—My question, which I direct to the Attorney-General, relates to prisoners who are serving sentence after having been committed of an offence against Federal legislation. Is a prisoner who is serving a sentence in a Queensland prison able to be considered for release on licence after half of that sentence has been served? Is this different from the situation which prevails for Federal prisoners who are serving their sentences in other States of Australia?

answer.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talk.start.para: —The short answer to Senator Colston's question is yes. The reason for this is that State offenders in Queensland are considered for release on parole in these circumstances. It has been in the past the policy in appropriate cases to treat Federal offenders in the same way as State offenders in the State concerned. This same general policy of treating Federal prisoners the same as other State prisoners in that State is applied elsewhere. As a result, where State laws provide, as they usually do elsewhere, for fixing minimum terms of imprisonment and for release on parole where a State offender has served a minimum term fixed by a court, a minimum term may, under the Commonwealth prisoners legislation, be fixed by a court in relation to a Federal offender in that State and the Federal offender may be considered for release on parole after serving that minimum term.

answer.para: Queensland law, by contrast, does not provide for the fixing of minimum terms of imprisonment by the courts. As I indicated a moment ago, offenders in Queensland serving more than six months imprisonment are considered for release on parole after serving half of their sentences without remission. That flows through to Federal prisoners in that State. The general situation as to Federal sentencing practice is the subject of a continuing reference now before the Australian Law Reform Commission. We are hoping that the Commission, in collaboration with Professor Richard Harding, the new Director of the Australian Institute of Criminology, will shortly be able to allocate resources to complete that sentencing reference.

There is a fundamental policy dilemma here as to whether we have a single national code for all Federal offenders, whichever State prison they happen to be in, or whether we continue to adopt what has been the past practice of treating Federal prisoners the same as those in the State in question. There are obvious pros and cons for both approaches. Traditionally, it has been a very difficult and contentious matter to sort out but we are still trying with the help of the advice giving agencies that I have mentioned.

talk.start.para: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Defence aware of the Premier of Queensland's public offer to use the Queensland Cairncross dry dock to repair the carrier HMS Invincible? What would the Government's attitude be to the Premier's public offer of support to our allies which would save it the enormous embarrassment of ratting on its friends?

—The Government is no more likely, in the present context than in any other, to have the Premier of Queensland handling either its foreign affairs policy or its defence policy for it. I am sure that with all the grace we can muster we will tell him what he can do with his dry dock in this instance .

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. I refer him to recent allegations that Australian migration officials in Suva were being both racist and sexist in their approach to applications from Fiji for tourist visas. Has the Government noticed these allegations? If so, have they been examined and is there any substance to them?

—I and the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs noticed the articles, particularly in one Sydney newspaper, making such allegations against the Australian High Commission in Suva, Fiji. Visitor entry from Fiji is approved for a short term stay, family reunion, tourism purposes, business purposes and, frequently, for medical treatment. Entry is approved on the clear understanding that visitors will not engage in employment or study and will depart by the end of such stay. They are not permitted to remain as settlers. But these criteria are applied universally and without discrimination on grounds of race, sex, religion or political opinion. The program will continue to be so administered.

—My question, which is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, relates to the most serious and devastating situation which exists in Africa at the present moment where it is claimed that over 6 1/2 million people are dying from the effects of long periods of drought. I ask the Minister: Firstly, is the Government aware that 14 countries stretching from the Red Sea across Africa to the Atlantic Ocean and down as far as Mozambique are suffering the effects of drought that, in some cases, has lasted for more than seven years, and that in Zimbabwe alone 62,000 children are dying from starvation? Secondly, what aid and other assistance is the Australian Government currently providing, through non-government organisations such as the International Red Cross, to these African nations? Thirdly, in the light of the severity of the prolonged drought and the resulting mass starvation, will urgent consideration be given by the Government to increasing immediately Australia's aid to Africa in an an effort to help alleviate the widespread hunger and suffering?

answer.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talk.start.para: —My briefing note on this matter is some two weeks old so it may need to be supplemented by further information if circumstances have changed . I can give the honourable senator the following information: Australia is bound to provide 400,000 tonnes of wheat or wheat equivalent under the terms of the Food Aid Convention which is part of the International Wheat Agreement. In 1983-84, Australian food aid to Africa will be valued at approximately $32.6m. African countries to receive that aid in the 1983-84 financial year are Mozambique, Tanzania, Ethiopia, Uganda, Kenya, Sudan, Madagascar, Somalia, Zambia, Mauritius and Egypt. In addition to providing relief for humanitarian reasons, Australian food aid does, of course, assist the economic development of recipient countries.

answer.para: I will come to the nub of the honourable senator's question which is about the drought stricken areas. The Government has been conscious for some time of the plight of African countries facing severe food shortages. In response to the continuing very difficult food situation in Africa about which the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organisation Director-General made a special appeal at the recent FAO Conference in Rome, the Prime Minister has confirmed to the leaders of three African Commonwealth countries, that is, Zimbabwe, Tanzania, and Zambia, that Australia will provide additional allocations over and above the amounts I have already mentioned that have been approved for 1983-84. This is a clear indication of the concern which Australia shares with other donors and United Nations agencies at the risk of starvation in African countries. It may well be that the amount of that additional assistance has now been determined since this note was written for me. If so, I will supply the honourable senator with such further information as I can, as quickly as I can.

talk.start.para: —Has the Minister representing the Minister for Health seen the report in the Adelaide Advertiser on Wednesday, 7 December describing the findings of the South Australian Public Accounts Committee in examining the school dental service? This Committee reported on the school dental service as a 'well-managed, cost effective and efficient organisation', but stated that the Dental Practitioners Association which had put 'ill-researched and inaccurate evidence' before the Committee had wasted public time and money. In the face of this clear affirmation of the school dental service, can the Minister say, first , when the Government will extend this excellent service to secondary school children and other needy groups, particularly pensioners? Secondly, will this be the last waste of public money in unnecessary evaluation on behalf of private practitioners in the profession?

—I have not seen the article referred to by Senator Crowley, but I certainly have an interest in the school dental service in South Australia and elsewhere, as my own State of Tasmania some years ago was the pioneer in this country in introducing such a health service and in introducing dental therapists. It later received assistance from the Federal Labor Government, and other States received assistance which was modelled on that. Certainly, whenever such a dental therapy service or school dental servie is established there are complaints from members of the dental profession who see it as a threat to their professional monopoly in this area. Therefore, I am not surprised at the Committee's report on the evidence, or at the reaction of the people in South Australia and the Committee to such evidence. From memory, it is my understanding that school dental service assistance is at present given through the community health grant. Certainly, this Government and the Minister will be interested in extending this service in this area. The difficulty at the moment, as in many things of this nature, is economic restraint. However, I will pass the honourable senator's comments on to the Minister, draw his attention to the article if he has not seen it and get an appropriate and detailed reply for the honourable senator.

—I refer the Attorney-General to the unprecedented and disgraceful Government appropriation of funds amounting to at least $1.25m for the promotion of the Yes cases at the referendum to be held on 25 February to the exclusion of the No cases. Can the Minister say whether any of this money has been spent? If so, how much has been expended? In what way has this been used? If the expenditure has been committed, who was responsible for authorising this action?

answer.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, the question is out of order because the matter is currently the subject of debate before this Parliament. I do not mind answering some aspects of it if I have your dispensation to do so.
—Yes. As I understand it, a House of Representatives message rejecting the Senate amendment is before the Senate. In that respect, the question is out of order if the matter is before the Senate.

—Mr President, I ask for your ruling. I understand that, prior to the amendment that was moved in this place and has been dealt with in the House of Representatives, the appropriation had already been made. I just wanted to know whether any of that amount was expended prior to the action taken by the Senate.
—I am able to answer that.
—I understand the Attorney-General is prepared to answer, so I might talk--
—In that case, sit down and let him answer it.
—I am now getting assistance from the Government Whip.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition has taken a point of order.

—Mr President, you raised the question whether the whole of the question was in order because of the situation of the Bill. That was a point of concern and I do not canvass your ruling. Following the explanation given by Senator Jessop, I suggest that elements of the question were in order. In particular, the commitment of funds and the extent to which those funds had been committed, and by whom and for what purpose, seems to me to be within the responsibility of the Attorney-General, or one of his colleagues and of public interest and concern. It seems to me that it is in order that those parts of the question be asked.

—I will allow the question insofar as it relates to the funds previously mentioned. I understand that the amendment before the Senate suggests that the funds be allocated equally. In that respect, I will allow the question.

—No funds have been formally appropriated in the sense that they have been the subject of line items in the appropriations for this financial year. Such moneys as have been expended, or in relation to which obligations to expend have already been incurred, have been forthcoming from the Advance to the Minister for Finance. As I indicated previously, the budgetary allocation in the normal course would be made up from the Attorney-General's Department's appropriations, being the Department responsible for consitutional form and the conduct of referendums. I cannot give an accurate indication of what money has been expended so far, but there have been already printed the information kits which were the subject of launch by me on 21 November and which involved packages essentially of parliamentary material-the second reading speeches, the Bills and the explanatory memoranda, with a short accompanying booklet. Some 10,000 of those have been printed for distribution to schools, libraries, business and trade union organisations, not for direct access to voters but for those in the business of communicating with people about these things. That money has already been spent. Some money has already been spent on market research and on preliminary arrangements with the advertising agencies. I am not in a position to specify how much, but I will do my best to find out and let the honourable senator know.

answer.para: The Government makes no apology whatsoever for proposing to spend money differentially on the Yes case in addition to that which is equally expended on the referendum pamphlet which goes out to all voters' letter boxes. The reasons for that have been amply and fully articulated by me in previous debate, and no doubt will be again. The importance of this to the Government is such that is it is clear that any attempt to continue blocking the capacity of the Government to spend money on the Yes case, which had bipartisan support, will clearly put the future of these referendums at risk.

talk.start.para: —My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer, is another good news question. As unemployment is at its lowest level for nearly a year and as the economy has grown in the September quarter much faster than was expected when the Budget was drawn up, is the Minister aware that statistics published today reveal that consumer spending in October was the highest this year? Is this not further evidence of the strengthening of the economic recovery?

answer.speaker: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the final part of the question is yes. Moreover, the bulletin before me shows that consumer spending is at its highest since at least July 1982. The bulletin in front of me does not go back any further. I am not sure how much further beyond July last year one has to go before one finds consumer spending at the levels that the Australian Bureau of Statistics survey showed for October. The reservation should be added about those figures that possible sampling errors are involved, but the seasonally adjusted figure for October over September represents an increase of 2.6 per cent, which is an extraordinarily high increase in one month. I repeat that caveat that there is in all probability some degree of sampling error in that figure. Coming on top of the quarterly estimates of national accounts, which again must be taken with some reservations because they are frequently revised from quarter to quarter, and which showed in the September quarter an increase in the non-farm gross domestic product of 2.3 per cent, or more than 9.3 per cent over the full year, the consumer spending figures for October reinforce the trends which have already been made apparent by a wide variety of economic statistics.

answer.para: It also appears to be correct that private investment in particular remains very slack. That is not unusual. In virtually every recession the pattern which has been followed is that consumer spending and replenishment of stocks precedes in the recovery phase the resumption of growth in private investment spending. So there is nothing unusual in the recovery which, clearly, the Australian economy is going through. There is no departure from the normal pattern of recovery from a recession and, hopefully, private capital investment at some time in the future will follow the trends that have been clearly established by a number of other indices.

I say again, as the Treasurer, the Prime Minister and various other Ministers have said, that the degree to which the recovery that is quite clearly under way is sustained is dependent to a much greater degree upon adherence to the prices and incomes accord than on all the other factors put together. Whether the recovery which is clearly under way is sustained and produces sustained economic growth rates at sufficiently high levels to make significant impacts on our very high level of unemployment depends to a very great extent, and probably crucially, on adherence to that prices and incomes accord. The Government cannot stress too strongly that it is vital that that accord be respected.

talk.start.para: —Can the Minister for Social Security advise the Senate whether any additional staff have been employed in anticipation of the Government's proposed assets test? If so, how are they being employed and from what funds are they being paid?

—There has been some recruitment of staff in anticipation of the introduction of the assets test. I am uncertain as to exactly how many, if any, have been employed to date. I will get the information as soon as possible and bring it back to the honourable senator.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is it a fact that the Victorian branch of the Minister's Department has frozen employment levels because it has worked itself up to a point of uncertainty as to the future passage of legislation?

—I will seek the answer to that flippant question from the shadow Minister for Social Security. No section of my Department has worked itself up to any state of uncertainty in this matter. The only uncertainty, I suggest, appears to come from the Opposition. First of all, we had its Leader saying that it would block the legislation. On the same afternoon the Leader of the National Party, Mr Anthony, said that the Opposition would not block the legislation, and on the very same day that the Leader of the Opposition made his statement that the legislation would be blocked Senator Messner at a meeting in Sydney said that the Opposition would not be blocking the legislation but only delaying it. So it seems to me that the only real uncertainty in this matter over the last few weeks has come from the front benchers on the other side of the chamber. I note that neither Mr Howard nor Senator Chaney, who were well known to be in favour of the reintroduction of the assets test in past years, had very much to say about it until they were instructed by the Leader of the Opposition.

speech.speaker: Missen Sen A.J.

talk.start.para: —by leave-I claim to have been misrepresented and misreported. I make this statement because I have been publicly misrepresented in an article which appeared in the Age newspaper on 10 December 1983. I have made copies of it available to honourable senators so they will know what I am speaking about, and I seek leave to have a copy of this short Age article incorporated in Hansard.

speech.para: Leave granted.
The article read as follows-
Use public cash for poll: MP
from KEN HALEY
CANBERRA.-Public funding, an established part of campaigns in the United States, may be used for the first time in Australia in February.

A Victorian Liberal, Senator Missen, yesterday suggested that public funding could be the way to resolve a Senate confrontation that has paralysed Government plans for television and radio advertising for the Constitutional referendums.
Under the system of public funding at elections, political parties receive a sum of taxpayers' money in proportion with their support at the previous election.

Applied to the five Constitutional changes proposed on 25 February, the Liberal , Labor, National and Democrat parties and Independent Senator Harradine, would divide up an agreed amount. Each would be free to promote the ''Yes'' or ''No'' case or both on the air and through television.

Pressure of other business yesterday led to the deferment until next week of the bill which would have authorised TV and radio expenditure for the ''Yes'' case only, if the Government's original plan had passed through Parliament.
Earlier this week, the Opposition and the Democrats amended the bill to disallow this spending which they said was partisan.
The Missen proposal is believed to appeal to the Attorney-General, Senator Evans, although he has made no public response to it.
Parliament last week passed legislation guaranteeing that public funding of political parties will occur at the next Federal election.

Still the most likely solution for the referendum advertising appears to be the equal spending of a specified amount-probably not much more than $500,000-on electronic media promotion of all the arguments for and against the proposals. That compromise was worked out by the Democrats and the Government on Thursday.

It is not known whether the Liberal Party would back Senator Missen's suggestion but the Democrat Senator Macklin said in Brisbane last night it had the advantage of making public funding common to all Australian polls.

But he said he could not see how it would achieve equity. ''There could very well be a decisive lack of balance. It's difficult to know which way it would go but the 'No' case could be massively disadvantaged.''

talk.start.para: —I thank the Senate. The article contains a number of misrepresentations that concern me. Even the heading of the article, 'Use public cash for poll: MP' is incorrect. I at no stage proposed the use of public moneys . This was a decision by the Government and any comment I have made is only as to the distribution which might be made of such money. The facts, Mr President, are as follows: Early on Friday morning I had a casual conversation, by chance, with Senator Macklin and Senator Mason of the Australian Democrats outside my door in a corridor of this building. It was at this time that Senator Macklin informed me that there had been negotiations the previous evening between the Australian Democrats and the Australian Labor Party involving, as I understood it, the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) and the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke , and that as a result of those negotiations, the amount of $1,250,000.00, which the Attorney had earlier disclosed was to be used for the promotion of the Yes case in the referendum campaigns in February 1984, was now to be divided equally between the Yes and No advocates. The precise amount of $1,250,000.00 was not mentioned in this conversation although I understood it to be the same amount that Senator Macklin was speaking about.

speech.para: This was the first I had heard of this arrangement and the only comments I made to Senator Macklin then or in our later conversation were that it would no doubt reduce the controversy, but it would be a somewhat unfair division because surely some part of the moneys should go to the Opposition parties, who have taken a stand on the referendum questions and will be campaigning on the referendum, and also to the Australian Democrats. I emphasise that this was a casual private conversation in the corridors and at no time did I make any public statement on the matter. I informed my Senate leader, Senator Chaney, of the information which I had just heard. He made inquiries and I was informed later that the Prime Minister's office denied any knowledge of this arrangement and my leaders had therefore assumed it to be a furphy. A short time later I happened to meet with Senator Macklin again in the corridor and told him that I understood that there was no truth in this proposal. He strongly reaffirmed it and gave me some detail about it. He said that the Government was preparing documents to cover it.

It appears that, later in the day, he conveyed my remarks to some representative of the Age newspaper, giving a clear impression, as honourable senators will see from the article, that I had made some public statement on the subject. This was not true. Furthermore, I made no reference in my conversation to public funding or giving any consideration to the new law in respect of public funding, which applies to elections. I would not have considered that law as directly appropriate to referenda campaigns, because the public funding arrangements are based upon first preference votes of candidates and are not, therefore, easily transferrable to the referenda proposals. The statement in the Age indicates that the so-called 'Missen proposal', which was a casual remark made in private conversation in the corridors, was some reference to the public funding arrangements and apparently the article makes no reference to my suggestion that the other parties as well as the No advocates should receive some funding to assist in campaigning if this were to be done at all. I want to emphasise that at no stage did the Age newspaper or any of its representatives speak to me or apparently endeavour in any way to communicate with me to ascertain whether I had made any statement or what was the nature of it. It will further be observed that the article reports as follows:
The Missen proposal is believed to appeal to the Attorney-General, Senator Evans, although he has made no public response to it.
It should also have said that the so-called Missen proposal 'is believed to appeal to Senator Missen, although he has made no public comment on it'.
It will be further observed from the article that Senator Macklin, having not only misconceived my comment, goes on to claim that he could not see how it could achieve equity. He said:
It's difficult to know which way it would go but the 'No' case could be massively disadvantaged.

The proposal which he puts forward as the Missen proposal is one which apparently does not make any provision for financial assistance to No case advocates and is quite contrary to the comment which I made. I must say, Mr President, that I do deplore the misuse of private and casual conversation in this way by both Senator Macklin and the Age newspaper. I can conclude only that it was designed to cause mischief in the Opposition parties. I might say that I do think there could be sensible arrangements whereby moneys could be provided for all parties and groups in the Parliament that desire fully to inform the electors about referenda proposals, but the details of any such proposal have not been considered by me.

speech.speaker: Macklin Sen M.J.

talk.start.para: —by leave-Senator Missen has claimed that I gave a clear impression to a reporter from the Age that he has made some public statement on the matter of public funding. He also said that he did not speak to the Age, so I have no idea how he was able to ascertain what I said to the Age. To make matters clear, I gave no such impression. At the time of the interview I was totally unaware of whether Senator Missen had made any public statement on the matter since I had been in transit to Brisbane and had only just arrived home when the Age reporter rang me.

speech.para: The reporter, in putting questions to me, seemed to have a full understanding of the various discussions which had taken place over the last couple of days. I do not know the source of his information, and even if I had inquired I am sure he would have refused to divulge his source. Like any good reporter, presumably he was on top of his story. At no stage did I give the impression that Senator Missen had said anything about public funding. I was unaware of Senator Missen's views on this matter as it affected the referenda campaign specifically in relation to public funding, if that is to be distinct from the way in which amounts of money are to be distributed. I spoke to the Age reporter about public funding and gave my view that a proposal to fund through political parties would have the advantage of bringing it into line with the electoral situation. The disadvantage is accurately summarised in the Age report referred to by Senator Missen.

In regard to Senator Missen's final point, that I was attempting to cause mischief in the Opposition parties, it would indeed be a pleasant thought if it could be achieved so easily. Unfortunately, the political situation is otherwise . But if it will help Senator Missen, I will state now what I have always thought to be the standing of his comments to me; that is, that it was an idea to be included amongst other indeas as a way around the impasse which currently faced the Parliament on this matter. As such it was indeed worthy of consideration and debate. I had in fact discussed this matter with some honourable senators. It was as a result of such discussions that I formed the view that, on the face of it, it would be unworkable. I presumed Senator Missen wanted the matter discussed with others otherwise he would not have passed it on to me. He did not ask that the source be kept confidential. Out of fairness to colleagues and others, I believe that unless specifically requested the source of various ideas for action with regard to legislation before this House should be made known to them. If Senator Missen is now saying that I should not raise his ideas about legislation with colleagues and others I will certainly accommodate him. However, in relation to Senator Missen's ideas on this and other matters I believe that that would be a pity.

talk.start.para: —by leave-To tidy up the facts, I do not recall being present at any conversation with Senator Macklin of the kind mentioned by Senator Missen.

talk.start.para: —I move:

I would like to comment briefly on the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation annual report. What is most impressive is the remarkable dearth of Australian application towards areas of renewable energy research revealed in the report. It is interesting that under the heading 'Institute of Energy and Earth Resources' on page 165 the Institute's aims are given as fostering:

. . . scientific and technological research aimed at contributing to the better definition, utilisation and management of Australia's mineral, energy and groundwater resources, with due recognition of the environmental consequences of these activities-
including planning the effective use of our energy resources and-
. . . consistent with the minimization of environmental stresses.

I would have thought that those aims would have been no more than pious platitudes, given the comments made in the rest of the report. When one gets into the nitty-gritty one finds on page 16 that 0.8 per cent of total research, that is under one per cent of the expenditure, and 0.9 per cent of professional research staff are being utilised in the field of renewable energy research. All of this is apparently devoted to research on solar energy systems. On Saturday night in North Sydney I spoke at a meeting under the chairmanship of Alderman Ted Mack. More than 200 people attended that meeting and they did so because they were interested in hearing Dr Mark Diesendorf and others talk about the very real possibilities of creating a significant area of additional energy in this country through the utilisation of known windmill generator technology.

It is of interest that last week I received from a Minister in this place a written reply talking about large-scale utilisation in the megawatt range of wind generators. A statement was made in this Parliament that these things were at the demonstration stage. I am impressed by the sort of Rip Van Winkle attitudes that we apparently have at the highest possible levels in our science and research areas. Machines of that type have been operating and delivering power under the grids of a number of countries for four years, yet we talk about these things being at only the demonstration stage. Apparently because of this we feel consoled by the idea that CSIRO is to do no work at all in this area this year. Other countries are spending millions of dollars on it. In Denmark hundreds of millions of dollars are being poured into this area, and it is proving successful.

The technology exists. Certain areas of this country, especially Tasmania, have been proven to have the best wind velocities and consistency in the world for the use of this source of renewable power. If this indeed is the case-it has been demonstrated to be the case-one would have thought that we would have been engaging in this research. The technology is known. We do not have to do any work. It has all been done for us. But no, some sort of blockage at the CSIRO level-or possibly in the policy area, which is more to the point-is preventing this research. Instead resources are being devoted to vain and rather silly projects such as shale oil. Look at the time and attention that was given to that project a year or two ago. The result has been a complete chimera.

If page 21 of the report is to be believed, the tiny amount of expenditure on renewable energy, moreover, was regarded as an expanded effort. That expenditure is less than one per cent of actual expenditure. Less than one per cent of the staff is being utilised in this area. The only direct reference to renewable energy research in the text of the report that I can find in the brief time I have had to look at it is half a sentence on page 14, which states:
In renewable energy research more attention was to research on high temperature solar selective surfaces . . .

It seems clear from all this that all research into wind energy has been or is being terminated and that CSIRO does not intend to begin any research into any other form of renewable energy technology. Unlike every other country, we are going backwards. We are retreating further and further back towards the nineteenth century, whereas all other major industrial powers are placing major emphasis on and are putting many millions of dollars into this important area of technology.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
