(14) Page 32, paragraphs 24 (3) (e), (f) and (g), lines 9 to 15, leave out the paragraphs, insert the following word and paragraph: ''and (e) if the level of assistance applicable in relation to the school were to be the level numbered 3 in column 1 of Schedule 8, the school would have reasonable prospects of long- term viability''.

speech.speaker: Macklin Sen M.J.

talk.start.para: — The Opposition's amendments seek to amend, first of all, clause 24 (3) (e), which states:

speech.para: the school has been the subject of adequate consultation with education authorities of the State;

I admit that I am not quite sure what that clause means. It does not mean anything in English so presumably it means something in draftese. The subject of that clause is missing. I presume that it is not the Minister as referred to in clause 3 (11). The assumption must be that clause 24 (3) (e) does not refer to adequacy of consultation between the janitor and somebody else so I suppose it must refer to the school authorities. It does not really make much difference, because sub-clause (3) (c), after all, is all-encompassing. It states:
the school has been recognized as a school by the State Education Minister of the State;

If that has occurred it means that it has been the subject of adequate consultation, as the Minister in each State is required to go through a process in order to decide whether to recognise a school as legitimate. After the meeting which was held between the State Ministers and the Federal Minister for Education, there is a hope that every State will follow a much more rigid and encompassing method of registering schools than has been the case in the past. I think that will be welcomed by everybody. We have debated this previously so I do not think there is any need for us to go into that. The Australian Democrats policy has always been that where a new school, whether it be a State or private school, is developed, it ought not be developed in such a way as to affect adversely either private or state schools. One should not read this clause as referring only to private schools. One should also read it as referring to state schools. I believe it extremely important that, in regard to where a state school is to go, there ought to be some discussion about whether there is likely to be any adverse affect on private schools. So it cuts both ways. We prefer that the clause remain. We would have preferred it to have been tougher, but the Government has made a decision not to have it so.

talk.start.para: —The clause refers only to non-government schools.
—Yes, but I am saying that it should be the case for both. Sub- clause (3) (g) states:

speech.para: the school has reasonable prospects of long term viability,

I cannot see anything unreasonable about that. The point that Senator Baume raised, I think, is possibly a fairly long shot. If one is to take a long shot on that, presumably one would take a long shot on sub-clause (3) (d), to which he did not refer. It states:
the school is not conducted for the profit, direct or indirect, of an individual or individuals;

I presume that any school would be conducted for the profit of individuals, that is, the children. If it is not it should not be funded at all, in which case one would object more to sub-clause (3) (d) than to sub-clause (3) (g). Surely sub- clause (3) (g) is self-explanatory. The situation is that one wishes to be sure that any school will have a prospect of continuing, and continuing for some length of time because, indeed, we are not here talking about recurrent funds only; we are talking about capital funds, and school buildings are not of much use to terribly many other organisations if a school vacates them.

I think it is extremely important that any responsible Minister has regard to long term prospects on a capital funding basis. I believe that money ought to be put into buildings only where there is a prospect that the school will continue over a reasonable time so the taxpayer can recoup a reasonable return on his investment. Presumably, sub-clause (3) (g) can be read in that sense only. The prospect of long term viability must be read in the total context because, from clause 3 (11) (a) (ii) one sees that the Minister is looking at it, in the totality of the situation, as an approved school. That totality would necessarily include the component of Federal moneys which may come to the school by way of recurrent grant. On that basis, the Democrats could not support the deletion of those provisions although we have that query about sub-clause (3) (e ). We do not accept the Opposition's amendments.

speech.speaker: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

talker.name: Senator RYAN
talker.role: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs)

talk.start.para: —The meaning of the word 'adequate' in the clause as drafted refers to the normal procedures of consultation between Federal and State authorities which, in respect of these matters, are pursued mainly through the work of the State planning and finance committees. Such consultation has proved adequate for certain decisions to be taken. We do not see any reason why it will not prove adequate in the future. However, it is important that the legislation make clear that there ought to be consultation. I am sure that the non- government schools involved will have their views about whether the consultation has been adequate from their point of view. I do not believe that the consultation procedures that the State planning and financing committees engage in when discussing the possibility of recommending funding for new schools has been the subject of criticism on the ground that it has been inadequate. I do not believe that there is any possibility of spelling out in legislation what would be adequate in the case of every possible school that is ever considered by any State planning and finance committee. I think Senator Peter Baume is quite familiar with the work of those committees. He would recognise that most clients or people discussing possible schools with the committees have found those procedures adequate.

speech.para: With regard to the question of long term viability, it is part of the responsibility of government to ensure that schools that are established and receive Commonwealth capital and recurrent grants are viable. It has not always been the case that schools receiving grants have been viable. I have heard of several instances of schools that have received capital grants from the Government not being viable because there was not enough community support or the programs turned out not to be satisfactory from the point of view of the parents of the children involved. Those schools have closed down after a few months, or a couple of years, of operation. Such a result is unsatisfactory for the Commonwealth because the Commonwealth loses money that it cannot easily regain. The State has usually, by that stage, also lost money. Of course, it is most unsatisfactory from the point of view of the children, who have the very destabilising experience of being put into a new school, finding that the school has collapsed and then having to find some other school to attend. I think a minimal requirement for a responsible government would be to ensure that a school is viable. Of course we are looking at the totality of the school's circumstance including its capacity to attract recurrent grants from the Schools Commission.

I do not accept the amendment moved by the Opposition, which tries to pre-empt the consideration that the Commission would give and tries to write in, as inevitable, a certain amount of funding, extrapolating from that that once category 3 funding was available the school would be viable. Even if category 3 funding were available for some prospective projects it may still be the case that the State planning and finance committee would consider them not to be viable. Senator Baume ought to be aware that communities put resources over and above what is available through category 3 funding into schools. If those resources were not available even the capacity to attract level 3 funding would not, of itself, mean viability. The Opposition's amendments are not acceptable.

talk.start.para: —I thank the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan). We do not agree. It is a difference of view, a different view of the world, perhaps. I do not believe the Minister gave us any idea of what is meant by 'significant adverse effect'. Those words are contained in sub-clause (3) (f). They form part of the words which the Minister has included in the Bill. We believe those words, likewise, are vague and subject to very wide interpretation. I raised this question in my previous remarks.

talker.name: Senator RYAN
talker.role: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs)

talk.start.para: —Again I think Senator Baume is anxious to try to have every possible case covered for all time in one piece of legislation. That paragraph announces the principle that there ought not be a significant adverse effect on existing schools. What would constitute significant adverse effect would vary from situation to situation. Obviously, if an existing non-government school was forced into closure because a new school started up next door to it, that would be a significant adverse effect. Obviously, if a government school was forced into closure because a new school was being provided alongside it, that would be a significant adverse effect. But clearly other matters are involved-things like the range of subjects available in a school, the extent of community support if it is a non-government school, and whether that community support is going to be withdrawn, have to be considered. A whole range of educational matters needs to be taken into account when the concept of adverse effect is being explored. It is not possible, and I do not think desirable, to try to cover all cases in one piece of legislation. I have confidence that the State planning and finance committees will be able to investigate these matters in an intelligent, rational and fair way. They are the bodies properly constituted to decide what constitutes significant adverse effects. Certainly the transfer of a few students would not constitute that, but in between that situation and forcing a government or a non-government school into closure there could be many circumstances which could be considered to be significantly adverse. Those circumstances are to be discovered and reported upon by the State planning and finance committees. They are not to be the subject of rigid pronouncements in a piece of Commonwealth legislation.

speech.speaker: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

talk.start.para: —I indicate on behalf of the Opposition that our concern remains. I agree with the Australian Democrats that it is very hard to know what is meant by paragraph (e), in spite of the attempts of the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs to explain it to us. We are still concerned about (f) and we do believe the extra words we propose for (g) are ones which should be added and we will therefore press our amendments.

speech.para: Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Peter Baume's) be agreed to.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the negative.

speech.speaker: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

talk.start.para: —Mr Chairman, there are more amendments to clause 24.
—You had six senators missing from that division.
—I am trying to address you, Mr Chairman. I do not know what is concerning Senator Chipp.
—That you are calling divisions and you have six people not here; that is what is concerning me.

—Mr Chairman, the Opposition will call divisions when it wants to, and I trust Senator Chipp will come in answer to the bells when they ring. The Opposition has some more amendments to clause 24 of the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Bill but they properly relate to some amendments that were moved to clause 23. I therefore suggest, as a matter of procedure, that it may be appropriate at this stage to postpone further consideration of clause 24. I therefore move:

speech.para: That consideration of clause 24 be postponed.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

speech.speaker: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: (6) Page 13, sub-clause 3 (20), lines 15 to 17, leave out the sub-clause.

The argument on this amendment was debated last Friday in Committee. It relates to the question of what is a developing area. The arguments are on the record. We believe this sub-clause should be deleted and I have so moved.

speech.speaker: Macklin Sen M.J.

talk.start.para: — The Australian Democrats' comments on this subject will probably best be made during the discussion of the Opposition's amendment No. 18 which refers to appeals. I propose to discuss why we do not support this amendment at that time because it will be a more all-encompassing discussion.

speech.para: Amendment negatived.
Clause agreed to.
Clauses 4 to 19-by leave-taken together.

talk.start.para: —I ask the Minister to direct her attention to clause 5 and to the provision in clause 5 for moneys for new arrivals receiving an education in English as a second language. I direct the Minister's attention to the amount of $862 which is made available as financial assistance for each eligible new arrival. I now draw the Minister's attention to the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Bill 1982 where, at the same point in clause 5, the amount of money made available was, I believe, an amount not exceeding $880. That amount of $880 was provided in a Bill passed at the end of 1982 and the Minister is proposing to make available only $860 in a Bill being put forward at the end of 1983. I understand that it may not be possible to apply a simple deflator for reasons which have to do with the kind of dollar estimates that were used. But nevertheless, there has been a significant reduction in the provision per capita for new arrivals receiving an education in English as second language. I ask the Minister to explain why this has been done and how she justifies it.

talker.name: Senator RYAN
talker.role: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs)

talk.start.para: —The officers are seeking the precise figures. But the figures that Senator Baume quoted for the 1982 Bill included a part for wage indexation for wage rises that did not occur. So it is being reduced in this Bill to $841. I draw Senator Baume's attention to page 67, line 36 of the Bill.
—I ask the Minister why the amount was reduced to $841. Does that mean she has provided less than the amount that last year's Bill made available?

speech.speaker: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

talker.name: Senator RYAN
talker.role: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs)

talk.start.para: —Yes. The Bill made available a prospective allowance for wage increases which did not in fact occur because of the wage pause. The amount of money has now been corrected to the amount of money that was actually allocated.

speech.para: Clauses agreed to.
Clause 20 (Approval of building projects and equipment projects in connection with non-government schools).

speech.speaker: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

talk.start.para: —by leave-There are two amendments to clause 20, Nos (7) and (8), which have been circulated in my name. I move:

speech.para: (7) Page 24, sub-clause 20 (5), definition of ''prescribed purpose'', paragraph (a), lines 41 and 42, leave out all words after ''non-government school''.
(8) Page 25, sub-clause 20 (5), definition of ''prescribed purpose'', paragraph (c), lines 4 and 5, leave out all words after ''non-government school''.

Very simply, the two provisions which we seek to amend are both part of the apparatus being put in place which the Opposition believes will limit the expansion of non-government schools. They impose requirements which will make it more difficult for non-government schools to expand. Two paragraphs of clause 20 (5) contain these words: 'not being a project the effect of which is, or is likely to be, to create additional places at that school'. We believe that this is part of the apparatus to restrict grants. We can see no reason why, if it is the recommendation of a planning and finance committee, and if the Minister wanted to accept that recommendation, there is any necessity for this to be written into the legislation. For reasons which we have set out on several occasions, we resist as a matter of principle the idea of limitation of the expansion of non-government schools by legislation such as this. We see it as part of an on-going attack upon non-government schools. The attempt to put restrictions upon the grants is, we believe, one of the ways in which non- government schools are being, as it were, constrained on a number of fronts. Because of that, I have moved both of the amendments and seek the support of the Committee.

talker.name: Senator RYAN
talker.role: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs)

talk.start.para: —The amendments are not acceptable. They seek to confuse the purpose of this part of the Bill, which provides for grants for the upgrading or improvement of existing facilities. Where there are to be new facilities, extensions or new places, those proposals must be the subject of the provision to which Senator Baume has taken exception. But I think it is perfectly sensible and reasonable to separate the provision of capital for the improvement or upgrading of existing facilities from the question of providing new places or extensions for which there is now laid down a proper procedure for gaining approval. So the amendments are not acceptable.

speech.speaker: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

talk.start.para: —Money may be granted to build new classrooms to replace old classrooms and the old classrooms may then become vacant. A school might previously have had old classrooms containing, say, 50 children and might want to put 20 children into the old classrooms, in what now might be perfectly satisfactory accommodation. It is precisely for that reason that we are opposing those words to which I have referred. We can see that the Minister, in providing for the upgrading of facilities in some schools where the facilities are poor, may be concerned to ensure that she is not going in by the back door and providing for major expansion. But it is possible in some circumstances for buildings or rooms to be made surplus and for those rooms then to be used to take small numbers of extra students. We think that while that may not occur often, it is a possibility. As I said in introducing the amendments, we are sensible to the role of the planning and finance committees in each State . We are sensible to the fact that advice would be given. But we think that those words contained in the Bill preclude what might be perfectly sensible arrangements in some circumstances where the money which is provided under this part of the Bill is used properly. It is possible that a school may be able to take a small number of extra students simply because space may become free which was previously used for the accommodation of, say, a large number of students. For that reason we press the amendments.

speech.para: Question put:
That the words proposed to be left out (Senator Peter Baume's amendments) be left out.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the negative.

speech.para: Clause agreed to.
Clauses 21 and 22-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 23 and 24-by leave-taken together.

speech.speaker: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

talk.start.para: —by leave-I move:

speech.para: (9) Page 28, sub-clause 23 (4), line 35, after ''have regard'', insert ''to the right of every child who attends a non-government school to a basic grant from the Commonwealth in respect of the education of the child at the school that the parents or guardians of the child have chosen and''.

(15) Page 32, sub-clause 24 (4), line 27, after ''have regard'', insert ''to the right of every child who attends a non-government school to a basic grant from the Commonwealth in respect of the education of the child at the school that the parents or guardians of the child have chosen and''.

These two amendments are identical in wording. They are important amendments because they state, among the matters to which the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) shall have regard in making the grants, that the principle that every child has a right to basic support shall be recognised. Mr Chairman, if one goes back through a whole series of annual reports from the Commonwealth Schools Commission one finds that the basic grant to children has been endorsed. The report which appeared early this year titled 'Recommendations for 1984' was merely the last in a long series of reports. I believe that every Commonwealth school report to government, up to that one had always recommended a continuation of basic support for every child in non-government schools. We have argued during the second reading debate, and at various other times, that we believe that every child should have some support for his or her schooling in whatever school the parents have chosen. This is a matter of principle. Including the words here merely indicates that the Minister, in determining the level of financial assistance, should have regard to the fact that every child is entitled to some support. This would not have the effect by itself of increasing or altering an appropriation, but it would be a recognition by the Parliament and by the Minister of this right which attracts to every child in every non-government school. It has been drafted in such a way that the Government can have it there without an embarrassment, without any problems with funding proposals. That principle could be inserted and recognised, as it has been recognised year after year by the Commonwealth Schools Commission in its reports to government.

Some quite disturbing things have happened lately. For example, Mr Van Davy recommended to the Commonwealth Schools Commission, when it was looking at options, that the zero funding option should be considered. He was one of the part time commissioners and he asked the Schools Commission to consider that proposal. Because that is known and because people are concerned that that kind of option is on the agenda, they want the words put in merely to get the principle identified. The Opposition will regard the vote on this matter as a vote about how people feel about the principle. The people who are listening to this debate will look at the vote to see how people regard that principle-the principle that every child who attends a non-government school is entitled to some basic grant from the Commonwealth. I invite the committee to support this amendment, being declaratory in nature and enshrining, as it would, a very desirable practice in school funding in Australia.

speech.speaker: Macklin Sen M.J.

talk.start.para: — This portion of the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Bill 1983, to which the Opposition has moved amendments, has appeared in similar Bills on a number of occasions. I take honourable senators back to the debate last year on the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Bill 1982 when Senator Peter Baume, who has just spoken, was Minister for Education. Clause 4 of that Bill was almost identical with the terms of this Bill. In other words, Senator Baume, when Minister for Education, found no need to include that principle in the Bill. The Liberal-National parties saw no need to include that principle. I quote the clause from last year. It states:

speech.para: The Minister shall, in determining for the purposes of sub-section (3) the level at which financial assistance is to be provided under this section to a school for the purposes of meeting recurrent expenditure of the school in respect of the year 1983, have regard to the need of the school for such assistance.

Senator Baume said that he would regard the vote on his amendment as a vote on whether or not one accepts the principle. I would like to quote from a letter that I wrote to the Catholic bishops in relation to a Press statement they issued on 1 September 1983. In that statement the bishops referred to two principles-one, the basic recurrent grant principle enunciated in the Opposition 's amendment; and the other the role of the Government in respect of those in need, a role which they reaffirmed. I wrote to the bishops in these terms:
I refer to the public statement issued in Canberra on 1st September, in which you vigorously re-affirmed your policy on the provision of funds for non- government schooling.

In the statement you refer to two principles; first the right of all children to share in educational funding and the second the right of those in need to receive more. The Democrats accept these principles also.

The Australian Democrats have argued constantly for increased education expenditure but to little avail. In the current situation, we are confronted with the fact that the House of Representatives has allocated a sum to non- government schools. The Senate does not have the power to increase the burden on the taxpayer and so . . . we must choose how to vote on the bill before us, however much we would like a different bill.

As a consequence the principles you raise in your statement are in conflict in the instance. If the basic recurrent grant is not reduced to some students those in need will not receive the full increase provided in the legislation.
If such circumstances arise-and I believe that they will-I would welcome advice . . .

That letter was sent to all Catholic bishops. I received a number of replies which alluded to the basic problem that we had raised-that confronted with only a Yes or No choice we could not have everything that we would want.

Under the current arrangement 2 per cent of schools come within category 1A, 13 per cent within category 1B, 7 per cent within category 2 and 78 per cent within category 3. Based on 1982 figures, 5 per cent of students are enrolled in category 1A schools, 12 per cent in category 1B schools, 3 per cent in category 2 schools and 80 per cent in category 3 schools. I would like to draw the attention of the Committee to the amount of money the previous Government gave per student to each of these categories and the estimated amount that the present Government proposes to give. After all, this is what we are being asked to vote upon. I remind honourable senators that the figures are comparable because they are based on 1984 prices. Under the previous Government, category 1A schools received $508 per student; under the current Government they will receive $381 per student. Under the previous Government category 1B schools received $500 per student; under the current Government they will receive $500 per student. Under the previous Government category 2 schools received $733 per student; under the current Government they will receive $741 per student. Under the previous Government category 3 schools received $885 per student; under the current Government they will receive $900 per student. In other words, in real terms the present Government is increasing the amount per student to both category 2 and category 3 schools and will provide the same amount to category 1B schools. This means that 95 per cent of students will have their basic grant either retained or increased.

The Democrats had little option when confronted with whether we should support the reduced funding to category 1A schools or support the proposal to reallocate the money to the 80 per cent of students in categories 2 and 3. We must support the reallocation of that money to those most in need. I have said elsewhere, I have put it in writing and I have now read it into the Hansard that we support the right of each child to receive support from the Government. We support the principle that each child in need should receive more than others from the Government. However, we cannot subscribe to writing into the legislation a principle which, first of all, the previous Government saw no need to write in and which, secondly, as Senator Baume said, is only declaratory and therefore will not have any legislative effect. The Bill would be held up if we were to do that. We do not believe it is fair or reasonable to ask that such a statement be put in at this stage and, therefore, we will not support the amendment. Senator Baume has made clear what he thinks he is voting on. I think I have now made it clear what we believe we are voting on. We accept the declaratory statement. However, we believe that if we were to vote to add the statement to the clause- and I remind the Committee that the previous Government felt no need to do this- we would hold up legislation which seeks to provide funds for all government and non-government schools in this country.

talker.name: Senator RYAN
talker.role: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs)

talk.start.para: —The Government cannot accept the amendment moved by Senator Baume, partly for the reasons that Senator Macklin has given for his Party's view of this matter but also because Senator Baume is seeking by attempting, most inappropriately, I think, to incorporate this declaratory statement to pre- empt the work now being carried out by the Schools Commission, that work being consultation with non-government school authorities to arrive at the best way in which our commitment to ensuring that all children have an adequate standard of resources for their education is able to be achieved. The extent of Commonwealth support for schools operating without ostensible needs is currently under consideration. We certainly could not countenance the pre-empting of the Schools Commission's report and of the proper budgetary decisions to be taken by the Government next year by accepting the inclusion in the legislation of this declaratory statement.

speech.speaker: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

talk.start.para: —It is necessary to respond to the significant point made by Senator Macklin, namely, why last year's legislation did not contain a declaratory statement. It will come as no news to anyone listening to this broadcast that the situation is different this year from what it was last year. Further, there was no suggestion last year that we should need to include those words. What we have this year is considerable uncertainty among non-government schools. I will just set out some reasons why this year it is necessary to have a statement on the principle. I say to Senator Macklin that, to people outside this place, a vote against the Opposition's amendment means no credibility. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) declared a week or two ago that the education policy of the Government is the education policy it took to the election.
—Right.

—'Right', says the Minister. The policy the Government took to the election is quite clear. That policy talks about phasing out support for some children. It is quite clear that support is to be reduced from 20 per cent, to 15 per cent, to 10 per cent, to 5 per cent and then to nothing. That is the policy on which the Australian Labor Party went to the people. If the Prime Minister was telling the truth and if that is the Government's education policy, that policy is moving towards a position of no support for some children. That is why it is necessary to include this statement in the legislation. We need to find out who supports and who does not support a basic grant for all children.

speech.para: The Prime Minister told us that the Government's education policy is the one that it took to the people. He gave us a clear signal that it is a policy which will result in the total phasing out of support for some children, if not next year, the year after or the year after that. However, that is the program. The policy is clear. It is a policy of progressive reduction and the future for non- government schools is, therefore, uncertain. I say to Senator Macklin that the circumstances of that policy, taken to the people by this Government at the election in March, has made it necessary for a statement to be produced. I go further and say: The Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) has been offered, in many places and in many ways, every opportunity to give assurances that a basic grant for each person will be maintained. A couple of moments ago, in responding, the Minister actually said that it would be inappropriate to give that assurance ahead of the work that is being done within the Commonwealth Schools Commission. The only interpretation of that answer is that the 'no funding' option for some children is a real possibility. If the 'no funding' option is not a possibility, this statement could be agreed to irrespective of what the Schools Commission is doing.

Everything this Government is doing-the Minister's answer two or three minutes ago and the statement of the Prime Minister-makes it quite clear that no child can be certain of a basic grant. The Minister has made it clear that the Commonwealth Schools Commission considerations, which she asked us not to pre- empt, do not necessarily promise a basic grant for every child. It is very necessary then that these amendments be considered.

I raise one final matter. The Senate is meeting this week to consider several pieces of legislation. I cannot accept the assertion that was put to this Committee that it is not possible to agree to any words in amendments such as these because the House of Representatives is not sitting. The House of Representatives can be brought back. The legislation can--

talk.start.para: —I never said anything about the House of Representatives.

—The honourable senator said that he did not want to delay the legislation. It would only be delayed for as long as it would take the House of Representatives to meet again. If this Senate is meeting this week and considering legislation it is possible in one piece of legislation or in several pieces of legislation that amendments or requests will be necessary. The fact that the House of Representatives is not sitting should have no place in our considerations. What we should look at are the principles and whether they are right.

speech.para: Some honourable senators in this Committee do not believe in a basic grant. That is fine; they will vote that way. Some do believe in it and they will vote that way. But one thing we cannot do is say that we believe in it and refuse to support it when we are put to the test. These are very important amendments. They are necessary this year. They have been made more necessary by the recent statements of the Prime Minister. The Opposition seeks support in the Committee for these two amendments which seek to add certain words, which will make it clear that the commitment to a basic grant for support for every Australian child is a support based on justice and is something with which this Senate wishes to be associated.

speech.speaker: Harradine Sen B.

talk.start.para: —I understand that we are debating an amendment to clause 23 (4) of the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Bill. I apologise to the Committee for not being present to participate in this debate until this moment. However, I wish to express my support for the Opposition's amendment to this clause. It is designed to enshrine in the legislation the ability of parents to uphold a most important principle; that is, the principle that the parents have a prior right to decide the education most suited to their child or children without penalty. This is an opportunity for people to stand up and be counted where it is most important for them to stand up and be counted; that is, in this Parliament. It is also a necessary measure to test just how far the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) or the Government, whichever it may be, is prepared to go with statements that have been made.

speech.para: In the second reading stage I gave the Minister the opportunity to withdraw a statement which the Canberra Times of 26 September 1983 reports she made. It is as follows:
The view that parents who chose non-government schooling for their children had a right or entitlement to government funding of that choice because they were taxpayers was a specious argument.

The Minister addressed herself to that question inadequately, I believe, in that she asked: 'What about the people who are not taxpayers?' If her excuse, as it were, for that statement is that she agrees that that argument is specious because it does not deal with non-taxpayers and the right of non-taxpaying parents to choose the type of education best suited to their children, let us hear that from the Minister. I would agree with her under those circumstances. My view is that, whether or not parents are taxpayers, somewhere, sometime the tax man will get them, their families, their extended families or, indeed, their children, who are being educated. The principle simply is the prior right of parents to decide the type of education best suited to the child without penalty and without an undue burden which would restrict that right.

It appears that there is an acceptance in this chamber by the Opposition, the Australian Democrats and me, that the basic grant principle should be upheld. On my way to Parliament I heard on the radio in the car Senator Macklin making comments about the basic grant. He has read into the Hansard his letter which upholds the basic grant. The problem he has with the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Bill-I suppose it is a problem that we all have with this Bill-is section 57 of the Constitution. We cannot increase the amounts of money that are made available in this Bill, or indeed in the cognate Bill, for education in Australia. I acknowledge that. However, as Senator Baume mentioned, this is declaratory in nature. As Senator Macklin accepted, it will have no effect in practice at this point in time for the disbursement of moneys.

But it is important, as Senator Baume has said, to incorporate in the legislation this year a principle of a basic grant for every child, whereas, as he said, it was not necessary last year. The only argument then against the proposal is that it may delay the Bill. I take up the point that was just made by Senator Baume. It will delay the Bill until next Friday. It will not delay the Bill any further.

talk.start.para: —It will if we insist on it. Presumably we would insist because we think it is important.

—That would depend entirely on what the House of Representatives did with it. We have all been in the business of politics for a fair time. We all know that we do not play all our cards at once. It would give members of the Government in the House of Representatives the opportunity of saying whether or not they agree with the concept of a basic grant for each child. I am sure quite a number of them agree with the concept of a basic grant for each child. As this measure is so important and so vital for the future of the children of this country, surely members of the House of Representatives will, in the meantime, give consideration to their position on this matter, having regard to all the statements that have been made broadly by education authorities. There will be no real delay.

speech.para: I take the point that was again made a moment ago that the Committee should not be confronted by the Government with a situation in the last week of sitting in which the Government is saying that the Bill will be delayed because the House of Representatives has got up for Christmas. That should not exercise our minds in any way and should not influence our votes on most important measures. This Committee has its responsibilities. If it chooses, in the exercise of those responsibilities to amend the Government legislation, it is necessary for the House of Representatives also to observe its responsibilities and consider what we have done. After all, this is the House of review. We have a right to review legislation such as this. If the amendments are rejected simply because of a decision by the House of Representatives to draw stumps and go home for Christmas, that is a pitiful way of looking at these matters. I urge the Committee to exercise its responsibilities fully in the knowledge that in so doing on this matter it is adopting a policy and incorporating in legislation a principle which the majority of honourable senators in this chamber agrees with.

talk.start.para: — The point I was making when I spoke in regard to the Bill being delayed was not so much as to whether the House of Representatives was sitting or not. I accept totally the point made by Senator Harradine that that is its problem, not ours. If the House of Representatives rejects the amendments, as it undoubtedly will because the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) has been able to give that type of assurance already, the Committee will be faced with whether or not it wishes to insist on them. Surely if that is the point and if we believe it is worthwhile putting in these amendments we would have to insist on their being put in. Under those circumstances I think that the present Government would probably use the same tactics the previous Government used in relation to the States Grants ( Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill 1982; that is, to say that if there is any hold-up on this matter, as Senator Baume said last year on the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Bill 1982, the universities and the colleges of advanced education will not get their funds. It is a tack that Ministers use. I suppose one can see how much is in the poker game. Quite frankly, I am not willing to play it either in relation to universities, CAEs or to schools.

talker.name: Senator RYAN
talker.role: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs)

talk.start.para: —I simply repeat that the declaratory statement that Senator Baume is seeking to add to the Bill is not acceptable to the Government. It is the case that all students throughout Australia are receiving in the Budget a recurrent grant from the Commonwealth Government; they are also receiving a recurrent grant from the State Government. We have put forward the redistribution and the funding arrangements which this Government has decided to make and we cannot accept any diversion from this by a declaratory statement moved by Senator Baume. I remind the Committee that the question of future funding arrangements is being addressed with great seriousness and great care by the Commonwealth Schools Commission in consultation with non-government school authorities. It is entirely unacceptable to the Government to have any attempt to pre-empt that consultation process and the decisions that the Government will subsequently make by the amending of the Bill in terms of this declaratory statement.

—I simply reiterate that the only reason why such a statement could cause difficulties for future programming is if there were on the agenda the possibility of some people getting no funds. If it is intended that everyone should get funds, nothing in these amendments will make it more difficult for the Commonwealth Schools Commission. If that is the case, if there is a hidden agenda and if we are going down the road the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) would like to travel, to put into effect the education policy he took to the election, which did include some people getting no funds, that would be a very good reason why the Government would not want to see these words accepted. It would mean that somewhere down the line a couple of years hence someone would get no funds. We think that this principle is worth stating and worth testing.

speech.speaker: Macklin Sen M.J.

talk.start.para: —I did not intend re-entering the debate. I wish to make the point that we pass this Bill every year. This year it has an amount of money allocated under it for private schools. Next year we will have another Bill. If that Bill does not provide the types of increases in funds that this Bill has provided, we need look not only at that matter but also at the other matters, such as making requests. I can say that quite openly. We are talking about the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Bill to which Senator Baume is trying to insert amendments. This Bill runs for only 12 months. We can see the amounts of money that have been provided. There is no hidden agenda; all the amounts of money are set out in the Bill.

speech.para: Question put:
That the words proposed to be inserted (Senator Peter Baume's amendments) be inserted.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the negative.

speech.speaker: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

talk.start.para: —I do not intend to move amendments Nos (10) and (16) as circulated. Instead, I move:

speech.para: Page 32, clause 24 (6), add the following paragraph:
(a) The Minister may, on the application in writing of the approved authority of a school, vary the list of non-systemic schools by omitting the school from that list.

The purpose of the amendment should be self-evident. It is merely to provide the Minister with the opportunity to respond to an application by a school, in writing, to be placed in a different category. It seems to me that there should be nothing exceptionable about the proposition, but I emphasise to the Committee that I move the amendment on its own and not in association with previously circulated amendments Nos (10) and (16) which sought to leave out words.

talk.start.para: —You are not moving Nos (11), (12) and (13)?

—They have been disposed of. Amendments Nos (10) and (16) related to the same matter, but we do not intend to move Nos (10) and (16) except that I am proposing the insertion of new paragraph (a) in clause 24 (6) in the words appearing in circulated amendment No. (16). I ask the Committee to support that. It merely gives the Minister the chance to respond if a school says that it wants to move from group 3 to group 2. It does not impose a duty on her to respond, but gives her that capacity.

speech.para: Amendment negatived.
Clauses agreed to.
Clauses 25 to 76-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 77 (Determinations to be in writing, &c.).

speech.speaker: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

talk.start.para: —by leave-I move:

speech.para: (17) Page 67, clause 77, at end of clause, add the following sub-clause:

'(2) Sections 48 (other than paragraph (1) (a)), 49, 49A and 50 of the Acts Interpretation Act shall apply to any instrument referred to in sub-section (1) as if in that sub-section references to regulations were references to instruments, references to a regulation were references to an instrument and references to a repeal were references to a revocation.'.
(18) Page 67, after clause 77, insert the following new clauses:
Appeals
'77A. An application may be made to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal for review of a decision made by the Minister in the exercise of a power conferred by sub-section 3 (11), 23 (3) or 24 (3).'.

Both these amendments seek to give some power of review of decisions. Amendment No. (17) seeks to add at the end of clause 77 a new sub-clause (2) which would bring within the purview of the Acts Interpretation Act certain decisions made by the Minister. The purpose is to make some of those decisions capable of disallowance by the Parliament. This merely seeks to bring to the Parliament the power to review some of the exercise of discretion or powers given to the Minister by the provisions of this Bill, which provisions we have not been able to have removed. It is not unusual for the Committee of the Whole to consider amendments which seek to have certain matters brought within the purview of parliamentary disallowance. The words used here to make such decisions subject to sections 48, 49, 49A and 50 of the Acts Interpretation Act are merely the device to make them subject to disallowance by the Parliament. Those who have been following the debate will be aware of the kinds of discretions and decisions which this legislation, when proclaimed, will contain. To have some of them subject to parliamentary disallowance seems to us appropriate.

Amendment No. (18) seeks to insert new sub-clause 77A. This amendment deals not with parliamentary review and disallowance but with the rights of applicants to appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal for review of decisions made by the Minister in the exercise of powers conferred. The amendment was drafted on the assumption that we might be successful in having certain sub-clauses omitted . The Australian Democrats' amendment was drafted, I take it, Senator Macklin understanding how the votes would go, on the assumption that we would be unsuccessful. Should Senator Macklin move his amendment seeking to add a number of other sub-clauses with regard to power conferred on the Minister, the Opposition would support them. We believe certain people may well be aggrieved by certain decisions made as a result of this Bill becoming an Act. It seems to us that an appeal is merely a right of citizens affected by administrative actions. If the actions are properly taken, it is in no way a threat to a Minister or a government. Governments generally do not like having their actions subject to review or appeal, but it is good for citizens. It is good, first, because it gives them greater opportunities and, secondly, because it increases their confidence in the whole system. The Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan), in her response to the second reading debate, indicated that she was not averse to an appeal mechanism. The Minister sketched out the bare bones of what she might have in mind. She said-and I do not disagree-that an appeal body should have some expertise. She said that she thought that it should be situated within her portfolio.

A number of questions remain unanswered, at least to me, in terms of what the Minister put up at the end of the second reading debate. They relate to the matter now before the Committee. First of all, if she allows appeals on decisions of the Commonwealth Schools Commission by an independent body, will that body be situated within or in relation to the Commonwealth Schools Commission? If so, it will be seen in some ways as an appeal from Caesar to Caesar. Will that body make decisions and determinations which the Minister will accept, or will it make recommendations? There is a difference in the way in which the appeal procedure would be perceived and the way in which it would be accepted. If the body could make decisions on appeal and if these decisions would be binding upon government, I think the Opposition would have some regard to that. But if the body is to make recommendations only, that is not good enough. We believe that there needs to be some appeal body which can set aside ministerial decisions or determinations if these are seen to be oppressive or in any other way inappropriate.

We propose two things. Firstly, we propose that certain actions by the Minister with reference to instruments or regulations shall be subject to disallowance by either House of Parliament. That is a perfectly normal procedure which we exercise occasionally and which applies to a large number of pieces of legislation and subordinate legislation. Secondly, we propose that an appeal procedure should be established and in the absence of a carefully spelled out alternative by the Minister. We are quite attracted to the Minister's proposition that there should be an independent expert appeal body, but until we have seen in detail what that body is to be or unless the Minister can set out for us in detail what that body will be, where it will sit and what its powers will be, we think an appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal may be the best of a difficult group of alternatives.

If the Minister wishes the non-government community to accept in good faith what she is proposing, I think she has to have in place an appeal mechanism which is seen to be fair and in which people can have some trust. In moving those amendments I ask the Minister in her response to give us what assurances she can and particularly to say what relationship her proposed appeal procedure might have to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Perhaps one member of that body might have some relationship to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. What we are seeking is some appropriate and accessible appeal mechanism for those who are concerned about decisions which may be made under the provisions of this Bill.

speech.speaker: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

talker.name: Senator RYAN
talker.role: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs)

talk.start.para: —The Government has given very careful consideration to the whole question of appeals in this area, as in all areas of government. I point out, as Senator Macklin has at a previous point in the debate, that it is surprising that the Opposition now finds itself so committed to the proposal that administrative decisions of the Schools Commissioner or by the Minister in this area should be appellable to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal when it had a number of years in which it could have made such a provision itself which, I think, would not have met with any opposition from the Australian Labor Party.

speech.para: I also point out for the benefit of people who may be listening to this debate that there is already in place an appeals mechanism within the Schools Commission which involves a very lengthy reconsideration by State planning and finance committees, an independent auditor and so forth. As far as I am aware there has been no complaint about the existing appeals procedure. There also exists for decisions made in these areas the possibility of an appeal to the Ombudsman or to the Federal Court of Australia. It would be very misleading if Senator Baume's comments were taken to suggest that currently no appeal is possible or that a great deal of dissatisfaction has been expressed with the existing appeals mechanism. Neither of those is the case.

However, following further discussions with Senator Macklin of the Australian Democrats I have thought further about improving the appeals mechanisms available to people who are dissatisfied with decisions by the Schools Commission or by the Minister. I have had discussions with my colleague the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) as to the appropriateness of making these decisions appellable to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The Attorney- General has taken the view that it would be appropriate to have the decisions made so appellable, but he agrees with me and I think with Senator Macklin and now, it appears, with Senator Baume that a specialist tribunal would be needed to give proper attention and consideration to the very specialised and complex matters that arise in putting schools into special funding categories and the acceptance of decisions of the Schools Commission with regard to planning procedures and so on.

I undertake and commit the Government to a constructive discussion with the Attorney-General, the Attorney-General's Department and the Schools Commission, with which I have not had adequate time to discuss this matter at length, and with Senator Macklin-if Senator Baume has further views on this I would be interested to hear them-so that we can establish a new appeals procedure which will have the characteristics of independence from the body which originally made the decision, which I agree is a desirable thing, expertise, so that the decisions will not be overturned by a body with no expert knowledge in this matter and the appropriateness of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. I am foreshadowing that we will establish a specialist appeals tribunal and that it will come within the umbrella of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

talk.start.para: —You say it will?

—That is the proposal. The proposal is that it will be an independent specialist tribunal under the umbrella of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. I should make it clear that the proposal will be discussed with the Schools Commission-I have not had an opportunity to do that-and, of course, by the Government. That is currently the proposal which the Attorney-General and I will pursue in a positive fashion.

speech.speaker: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

talk.start.para: —The Opposition has moved two amendments. I wish to respond positively to what the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) has just said. The Minister has given the Committee some undertakings. I understand that she has undertaken to open up discussions with a view to establishing a tribunal which has independence and expertise and which is within the umbrella of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. This is what the Opposition was seeking. It seems, if we pick up the point made by Senator Macklin not long ago, that we have not infrequent opportunities to look at the operations of the Commonwealth Schools Commission. I am willing now to seek leave to withdraw amendment No. (18) on the understanding that we will be guided by experience. If we set up the kind of appeals procedures envisaged and if it is as it seems it might be, I believe it would meet our needs and the needs of non-government schools. They want a reasonable appeal process. As a first step I seek leave to withdraw amendment No. (18) circulated in my name on the understanding that on a subsequent occasion we may want to come back down that road if the need remains.

speech.para: Leave granted; amendment withdrawn.

talk.start.para: —That leaves amendment No. (17) and the question of disallowance of appropriate instruments and Acts. I am not trying to be combative now but there is a perception that things are different. There is a new policy, a new government and groups of people are concerned about some of the new powers which are vested in the Minister in the Bill. This Bill extends the powers of the Minister in significant areas and to seek to have a power of disallowance is not considered inappropriate.

speech.speaker: Macklin Sen M.J.

talk.start.para: —I do not propose now to go ahead with moving the proposed amendment I have circulated which is similar in wording to amendment No. (18) moved by the Opposition. I think that the assurance given by the Minister is precisely what the Australian Democrats were also seeking. I must admit that we were not too successful in getting that type of assurance from the previous Government, and I hope that the current Government will give us such assurances more often. I believe there is a settled view, and I presume it is shared by all parties, that where an evaluative decision is to be made by the Minister, it is the right of a citizen to be able to make an appeal on that decision, which is not as onerous as taking it to the Federal Court of Australia , which could be an expensive business particularly for a poor school. A less onerous and more effective way to deal with most matters has been to establish a specialist committee under the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. I think that the specialist committee is needed for one other reason and that is that most of the evaluative decisions which may have to be made on appeal would be of such a nature that if they were not made in a very short space of time after the appeal , there would not be much point in pursuing them, because the effect would be such that the school involved would probably not be around.

speech.para: We believe the other amendment moved by the Opposition is reasonable. We cannot support it here, but I certainly appeal to the Minister to look at the notion contained within that amendment, which is certainly worthy of support. We hope that at a later stage, and certainly the next time this Bill comes before the Senate, an amendment will be included to allow such instruments as were included in the Opposition's amendment which provided for the possibility of making some disallowance in relation to the definition of what might be a developing area under sub-clause (20). That was probably the idea that Senator Baume had in mind so that that determination or some other determination or instrument issued by the Minister might also be able to be the subject of scrutiny by this chamber.

speech.speaker: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

talker.name: Senator RYAN
talker.role: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs)

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Baume and Senator Macklin for their co-operative response to amendment No. (18). The Government does not accept amendment No. (17 ). The undertaking I have now given with regard to the proposed provisions for appeals to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal might answer some of the anxieties which prompted the moving of amendment No. (17). Basically the problem is this: The number of administrative decisions concerning the declaration of areas is such that it would be a serious impediment to the work of the Commonwealth Schools Commission and to the operation of schools if decisions regarding their funding were to be made subject to disallowance in this place. Delays which schools cannot afford to tolerate would inevitably follow.

speech.para: Non-government schools, particularly, constantly say that what they most need is security and the ability to know where they stand and plan their year's program accordingly. If a number of decisions regarding their capital or other entitlements were to be made and then not secured because of the possibility of their being disallowed in this chamber, I do not believe that that would be in the best interests of the proper operation of those schools. I believe it would place intolerable burdens on the operation of the School's Commission, which would not know what money it had available until the time allowed for disallowance in this chamber had elapsed. I do not think the amendment is necessary. I am not aware of decisions of the Schools Commission having been such that any recipient of funds has felt the need to have decisions of the Schools Commission subject to disallowance in this chamber. There will be an improved appeals provision. If we were to go too far along the track of making every administrative decision of the Commission or the Minister in this regard, subject to disallowance in this place we would have planning and administrative chaos.
Amendment negatived.
Clause agreed to.
Remainder of Bill-by leave-taken as a whole, and agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

speech.speaker: Hill Sen R.

talk.start.para: —I respond on behalf of the Opposition to the second reading speech of the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Senator Button) on the Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1983. The Opposition does not oppose this Bill. In fact, many of the changes might be described as part of the ordinary ongoing process of government. They make for improvements in administration and are therefore supported. In other areas the Opposition is concerned not with the proposed provisions when taken at face value but with what might be the Government's motivation and how in practice it will implement such provisions. In other words in the area of health reform so far in this Government's first year we have witnessed a growth in government bureaucracy, a corresponding lessening of the role of the private sector and a reduction of the freedom of choice for both health providers and patients. What we are having implemented appears to us to be a less efficient health service at what will be a greater cost.

speech.para: We have that situation, because of the ideological bent of this Government, the mentality that government knows best and provides best, that people should not be encouraged to look after their own affairs, and that they should accept being herded to comply with the restrictions of socialised medicine because it is in their best interests. When we look at the Bill, which in its most important parts is a health reform Bill, this time in relation to support for patients requiring nursing home accommodation-in other words, largely concerning care for the aged-we do so with some trepidation. We examine it in accordance with the goals that we think are important and which those who support us think are important; for example, that all Australians should be encouraged within their financial situations to plan for advanced years and the possibility of the need of such nursing care.

Nursing home care should nevertheless be available to those who are in need. It should be of a high standard. It should be provided in a pleasant, compassionate environment. That means as far as possible keeping patients within their own communities. The care should be provided in the most economically efficient manner, and Australians should not be forced into nursing homes by the lack of facilities more suitable to their personal situations, which is obviously not in their individual best interests or the nation's best interests. These are the types of considerations we take into account. On perusal, the Bill appears to be not inconsistent with our objectives. Nevertheless, because of the Government's ideological blinkers, which we have seen operate this year in other areas of health care, and because of certain statements made by the Minister in his speech and by other Government members in debate in the other place, we remain concerned. The Minister stated:
. . . Australia overall has very adequate provision of nursing home accommodation . . .

The implication is that we can rest on our laurels. Many areas, particularly in some country communities, are inadequately serviced by nursing homes. Applying our test-that such care should be available to those in need and desirably within their own communities-we are concerned lest the Minister is hinting at downgrading this program. That appears to be what he is doing because he continues, in his second reading speech:
The priorities of the Government as expressed in its election policy for the care of the aged are to moderate growth in the nursing home sector.

I remind the Senate that since this Government came to power there have been no approvals-which is more than merely moderating growth. I also remind the Senate that it is not only private developers-and one suspects that much of the Government's concern in relation to this matter flows from its ideological views -who are having to bear the cost of this standstill, but also communities that have raised funds for building projects and are now seeing their efforts eaten away by cost rises, as well as prospective patients. The Minister for Health (Dr Blewett), in replying to the second reading debate in the other place, said that the delay was only temporary; that in the New Year he would put on extra staff in order to catch up. That is inconsistent with what he said in his second reading speech. I simply say at the moment that we remain sceptical and will keep the matter under constant attention, as is our responsibility.
The Minister also stated that his Government:
. . . will encourage the further development of hostel, community and domiciliary care services.

We applaud this development but perhaps for different reasons. The implication in the Minister's speech is that the provision of such alternatives is cheaper. Some studies are now suggesting that that may not be so. We applaud what is proposed because such facilities may be a better alternative for the person or persons concerned. Consistent with our views on freedom of choice, we would rather that a person who wants to stay in his or her home have the opportunity to do so. We certainly do not see such encouragement as justifying the non- provision of nursing home accommodation for those who prefer that alternative.

We note the administrative changes in the approval of new and additional nursing home accommodation. The change that the Minister, rather than the director, will now approve applications-which means that the decision is capable of being reviewed by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal-is welcome. Also, the principles upon which assessment will be based will be brought before the Parliament. This means that we will be given an opportunity to debate the matter . That too is appreciated. However, we are somewhat unsure of what this means in relation to the Minister promising to put on extra staff in the New Year to overcome the backlog of applications. There appears to be an inconsistency which the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) may care to clarify. We hope that community groups and private enterprise concerns will also have the opportunity to contribute to the formulation of these guidelines. Again, the interests of country areas come to mind. In those areas the economies of scale which the city enjoys may not be available but there is still a need on the part of the communities concerned, and people should be given the opportunity to put their views to the Government. In the past they have shown their interest and concern by their willingness to raise funds for such nursing home projects.

The Opposition notes the new provisions allowing the Minister to invite interested persons to make application for a nursing home in a specified region. We reacted somewhat suspiciously to this. It appeared that community initiatives , which we have encouraged, would be further subordinated by bureaucratic assessment. However, in his reply in the other place the Minister elaborated on the shortcomings of the first come first served system. They are shortcomings which we recognise. We also recognise that the Government, as the custodian of the people's money, must support the best project. Therefore, if the system is to operate as we now understand-that when applications are made for approval the Government will advertise, to give others an opportunity to submit proposals-it seems to be reasonable. However, we will be interested to see how it works in practice. It is interesting to note, from the examples the Minister gives, that in all cases private enterprise is seen as the villian-opportunistically leaping in in front of community groups. It may well be that certain altruistic community groups, though well meaning, will not be able to see such a project to completion. The assessment must be made in the best interests of the patient. The Government, as guardian of the public purse, must keep in mind the cost to the taxpayer. We applaud that and we will watch with interest the development of this new assessment method.

In touching upon the Government's responsibility to the taxpayer, I have been interested to see figures, submitted by the Commonwealth Department of Health to the Senate Select Committee on Private Hospitals and Nursing Homes, which appear to indicate that the operational costs of privately run homes are considerably lower. No doubt the Committee will compare the quality of the service given but it tends to confirm what we on this side suspect, that privately run nursing homes are the most cost effective method of providing a service in this area. I do not say that the Government sees all private nursing home proprietors as unscrupulous, although that does seem to be the view that improperly pervades the Australian Labor Party's attitudes to these matters. The Minister, in his second reading speech, stated:
There is a need to protect patients from the unscrupulous practices of a few nursing home proprietors.

Let us be clear. The Opposition accepts the responsibility of government to protect those who are unable to protect themselves. However, we also recognise the major contribution that private nursing home proprietors have made to the betterment of society and that many, if not most, go well beyond their obligations to ensure that a nursing home is a real home away from home.

This brings me to the fee control system. We have accepted that this Bill offers a small improvement in this area. The Minister has foreshadowed a change to the system-to one of program grants-and we will be watching closely the change in operation. I remind the Senate that private nursing home proprietors boast that they set the pace in high quality care as well as in offering a service that costs hundreds of dollars per patient per year less that it would in a Government institution. By and large the private and voluntary sectors have a proud record in relation to the provision of aged care in this country. We look forward to their continuing to be the main providers in the future. We recognise their entitlement to be adequately rewarded and we will look to protect that interest.

Apart from an assessment of suitable nursing home projects, the Bill also deals with the assessment of suitable patients. In practice, in the past this assessment has been made by the patient's general practitioner. Although technically it is formally made by the Commonwealth medical officer, it is made upon the recommendation of the patient's personal GP. The Government has a view, in the words of the Minister, that a conservative 20 per cent of people are inappropriately located in nursing homes. The Government is to change this for the future by the use of these assessment units. We query what is happening in relation to those already in homes but certainly for the future the role of the new assessment units will be to change that percentage.

We are yet to see how these assessment units will operate in practice. We accept, as the Minister said, that aged persons are happiest and best cared for when they receive that level of care appropriate to their needs. We accept also that a GP might not be the best judge, that other professional skills can play an important part in the assessment. But we fear coercion. The judgment seems to have been that at least one in five people now going to a nursing home should be going somewhere else. The assessment units are to be the mechanism to achieve that gaol. We are therefore concerned, and this is another area where we intend to watch application carefully.

There are a number of other matters I should mention. The first relates to friendly society pharmacies. Clause 53 of the Bill provides for the repeal of section 91 of the National Health Act. I remind the Senate that section 90 deals with the approval of a pharmaceutical chemist to supply pharmaceutical benefits. Section 91 limits the number of friendly society dispensaries which can supply pharmaceutical benefits to all members of the public. They are limited on a State basis to the number in existence from the commencement of that section of the Act. Those so limited are limited, in fact, to supply principally to members of the friendly society, their spouses and their children. I understand that there are eight such limited approvals in Australia-five in Queensland and three in South Australia. The deletion of section 9 will therefore have the effect of removing the restriction with regard to those eight pharmacies. The Pharmacy Guild of Australia, as honourable senators will know, has expressed concern.

talk.start.para: —What are they worrying about?

—What they are saying is that to lift the restriction will enable friendly societies, which are presently so restricted, to compete with them on an unfair basis. They are saying that friendly society pharmacies have an unfair advantage. They usually say that from a taxation point of view eight pharmacies within the whole of Australia are presently limited and that, therefore, if that restriction were lifted a further eight pharmacies would be able to compete with them in the sales of prescriptions to the public. I should have thought it was clear that to lift this restriction on only eight pharmacies would represent only minimal, insignificant additional competition to the pharmacy profession. The Guild, however, goes further and expresses the fear that to lift the restriction will lead to an avalanche of new friendly society pharmacies. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a short table which indicates the shortfalls in approvals that presently exist in New South Wales, Victoria and Western Australia.
