talk.start.para: —A glance at the table will indicate that in Victoria, for example, the number of full approvals available is 65, only 32 of which have presently been taken up. In Western Australia the number of full approvals available is ten, only one of which has been taken up. In New South Wales, the number of full approvals available is 16, only four of which have been taken up. This table clearly indicates that even with the current restriction there is room for what might be called an avalanche within the profession, but it simply has not occurred. Given the considerable shortfall already in existence, we have been unable to see how the pharmacy profession would be any worse off by a lifting of the restriction. We therefore believe that the fears of the Pharmacy Guild are not well founded. On the other hand, we accept that the pharmacy profession is undergoing the difficulties that all small businesses are experiencing in this country.
—Too many of them.

—Senator Georges says that there are too many of them. I should mention that there are State legislative restrictions, certainly in Queensland and South Australia, so that any fear about the proliferation of friendly society pharmacies in those States, even with the lifting of the restriction, is clearly not well founded. However, that does not answer the question as to whether friendly society pharmacies are in a more favourable taxation position. That is clearly a debate for another day. We on this side of the chamber accept the general principles of taxation-simplicity, equity, and efficiency. Efficiency in that context means that the method by which a business is operated should not make any difference to the taxation consequences of that business. In other words, one should look for neutrality. It is not as easy as that to judge the position in relation to friendly societies because they in turn will come back and speak of the particular investment restrictions they face under State law.

speech.para: The subject is therefore complicated. It is an important subject and one that I understand will be considered another day, perhaps when the relevant, proposed legislation of this Government is considered. Nevertheless, in the meantime we believe that the lifting of the restriction will not detrimentally affect Guild pharmacies to any significant extent. On the other hand, it will offer some small advantage to the public because the eight pharmacies that are presently caught within the limitation will be able to offer their prescription service to the total community and not just to members and their families. Again, however, we accept the responsibility to monitor closely the application of the section.

The amendments to the isolated patients' travel and accommodation allowance scheme will allow greater flexibility in the operation and administration of the scheme. For example, as the Minister stated, they will allow the extension of benefits to patients referred by an optometrist to an ophthalmologist and by a dentist to a specialist or consulting physician for a treatment arising from a dental service. We support this scheme. We wish to encourage further decentralisation. We recognise the additional costs to those who live in more distant areas and therefore the responsibility of the total community to help contribute to that additional financial burden. We therefore support these amendments. We believe that it is reasonable to argue that there are still anomalies within this scheme that should be kept under review and should be able to be overcome in the future.

This is a large Bill. It comprises 76 clauses and covers many other matters. As I indicated, most are administrative changes, all of which we are prepared to support. I do not intend to take up the time of the Senate in the current circumstances in running through each of them. Therefore, in summary, we do not oppose the legislation. On its face, it introduces potentially beneficial changes. However, some changes have the potential to be applied in a way that may be detrimental to the interests of the Australian people. In regard to the application of the provisions in practice, we shoulder our responsibility to accept a role of continuing monitoring, and that is what we shall be doing in relation to the application of these provisions.

speech.speaker: Crowley Sen R.A.

talk.start.para: —The Health Legislation Amendment Bill ( No. 2) will amend the Health Insurance Act 1973, the National Health Act 1953, the Nursing Homes Assistance Act 1974, and the Medical Research Endowment Act 1937. It addresses a number of changes covering a wide spectrum of bits and pieces. It could almost be called a housekeeping Bill. It is addressing changes concerning nursing homes, health card arrangements, the isolated patients travel and accommodation scheme, changes related to social security benefits and overservicing provisions, and it contains specific clauses concerning patients with cleft lip and palate conditions. It also addresses casual vacancies in the membership of the Medical Benefits Advisory Committee, access to information under the secrecy provisions of the National Health Act, changes in the Medical Research Endowment Fund, and the removal of restrictions on the number of friendly society dispensaries.

speech.para: The Government has introduced this Bill to amend a number of pieces of legislation, in some cases by bringing them into the 1980s. In particular, the changes to the Medical Research Endowment Act 1937 essentially acknowledge that a fund of $37.9m for 1983-84, which is an increase of 28 per cent over that for last year, indicates, first, the Government's commitment to medical research, and, secondly, an appreciation that a fund of such size should conform to modern requirements of auditing and financial management. This Bill will bring it within the public account and the concomitant audit and accounting provisions. There will be changes in the provisions for investment of surplus funds, but the authority for approval of grants will remain with the Minister for Health. The Government will maintain its commitment to foster and encourage excellence in medical research in this country.

The isolated patients travel and accommodation allowance scheme has been extended to patients referred, as Senator Hill said, by an optometrist to an ophthalmologist, or by a dentist to a specialist or consultant physician. It also makes changes in terms of hardship cases, where interim payments can be made rather than payment at the end of the travel arrangements. Many people cannot raise the money for fares and/or accommodation costs, and the financial burden is something that people do not want at a time of sickness and continuing need for treatment. So the provision of interim payments for those who can justify a case for that to happen because of their need are to be commended.

The other important amendment in this area is some flexibility in approval for further specialist treatment. I know myself of the problem of a woman with a child who has the need for a splint leg, an artificial leg, who lives at Port Lincoln. To travel to the city is a very expensive business, but as the child grows, so the splint needs to be changed or modified, or there is need for a different and larger replacement. At present the isolated patients travel allowance allows money only for referral to specialists. In this case the child is attending a splint maker, not a medical specialist, and has always been excluded from the provisions of this allowance. I understand that the flexibility allowed to the Minister means that such cases as that may be given consideration.

The other important extension in this amendment is to assist families where a patient, attendant or escort dies away from home. In part, it will cover the cost of returning a body to the home and friends for burial. It is a particular problem that is likely to occur, as we are dealing with ill people who have been referred to places far from home for medical treatment and continuing treatment. It is quite likely that such people may die. The cost for returning a body to the home is very large. It is very important and very good that this Bill makes provisions for that circumstance. The cost of the isolated patients travel allowance has increased by 45 per cent from 1981-82 to 1982-83. This year's allowance allows for an increase of 37 per cent. However, the increase in flexibility and changes in accommodation estimates and payments provides for more flexible distribution of that money and, hopefully, will cover the requirements on that grant this year.

There will be a removal of the restrictions on the number of friendly society dispensaries in each State to allow them to supply a full range of pharmaceutical benefits to all members of the public, and not just to members of the friendly society. It does away with discriminate legislation under section 91 of the Act. As Senator Hill said, it relates to only eight pharmacies, three in Queensland and five in South Australia. The options for this in other States already exist but there has not been a mindless expansion in the other States. Other pharmacists have not been ruined. It is important to consider these matters broadly and thoroughly. But there is little reason to anticipate the problems that the Opposition or the Pharmacy Guild of Australia has raised. I should like to quote from the Hansard report of the House of Represenatives debate, at page 2916. The shadow Minister for Health, Mr Carlton, said:

However, normal businesses compete successfully with co-operatives in a number of areas of the economy, and it is therefore difficult to justify imposing trade restrictions on co-operatives in this particular area.

Further, the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) also addressed this very point in the House of Representatives. He pointed out, first, that South Australia and Queensland have special legislation that prevents any exploitation or further development in those States, and that where the examples exist, in New South Wales, Victoria and Western Australia, there has been room for many years for expansion but it has not been taken up. So the pharmacies have not been affected by the legislation disadvantageously. There is little reason to fear that these changes, which allow for only eight extra pharmacies fully to dispense pharmaceuticals, will make a considerable difference.

The changes in relation to nursing homes are in line with the Government's policy of redirecting the nursing home dollar towards domiciliary care and facilities to help people to continue to live in their homes or in hostel accommodation where assistance can be provided in a form related to specific needs, rather than unnecessary full nursing home care. Up until now, most of the provisions for the elderly under nursing home provisions required or led to the expectation that people would become fully bedridden, or at least that they would be provided with a full range of provisions for themselves as a patient in a hospital. It has been an exercise in overkill. There are a number of people who need full nursing home facilities and full nursing care, but the estimate of 20 per cent of people who are inappropriately placed in nursing homes is reasonable.

The question of cost here is also very important. Nursing home costs to the community and the health bill are very large. In the same debate in the House of Representatives, the honourable member for Grayndler, Mr McLeay, cited statistics that show that in 1976-77 the Commonwealth appropriated $285m for institutional care, but in 1982-83, the year of the last health budget presided over by the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton), the Commonwelath appropriated $848m for institutional care. That is approaching a four times factor over that period. In the same period the Commonwealth payments for home care rose from $32m in 1976-77 to $77m in 1982-83. In other words, the growth in cost for institutional care far exceeded the growth in cost for domiciliary care or home care provisions. This Government is very concerned to assist people to stay in their homes if that is their choice. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

proctext.para: Debate resumed from 9 December 1983, on motion by Senator Ryan:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
Upon which Senator Durack had moved by way of amendment:
', but the Senate, whilst welcoming the intention of the Bill to remove discrimination against the people on the basis of their sex, marital status or pregnancy, is of the opinion that:
(a) the Bill should not rely on the external affairs power as a head of power;
(b) Australia's signature to the United Nations Convention on the elimination of all forms of discrimination against women should not be used to extend the powers of the Commonwealth;

(c) the removal of discrimination against people on the basis of sex should be recongised as not obliging anyone to enter the paid workforce or alter their view of their responsibilities towards their spouses or children;

(d) no decision or action by any educational or child care or other body established for the education of students or the care of children in accordance with the doctrines of a religion or creed or in accordance with stated principles should be affected where that decision or action has been taken in good faith to enable the body to conform with those doctrines or principles;
(e) nothing in the Bill should be taken as approving those articles of the Convention which are not implemented by the Bill; and
(f) the clauses of the Bill should be re-drafted accordingly'.

speech.speaker: Martin Sen K.J.

talk.start.para: —The Senate was debating the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 (No. 2) last Friday and I was speaking when the Senate adjourned at 4.15 p.m. I was in the process of making some statements about traditional forms of discrimination against women and the grounds on which they were based. I was making the point that it had been thought, in the light of statistics, that forms of discrimination on the grounds of facts about the high rate of job turnover and absenteeism amongst female employees were thought to be soundly based. The advent of the assembly line since World War II changed a lot of thinking in relation to women as employees. It was revealed that the undesirable employee characteristics of a high rate of job turnover and absenteeism were not something that were sex specific as they had been thought to be previously.

speech.para: As industrial sociology grew as a discipline it was discovered that these characteristics were also characteristics exhibited by men under certain circumstances-circumstances which increased in their incidence with the assembly line. It was found that they were in fact job-related characteristics. A very large body of evidence shows that when people are employed to perform menial work with low challenges to their initiative, intelligence and skills, particularly if they are people with some intelligence, they can be expected to change jobs frequently because of the nature of the jobs and their dissatisfaction with them. They can be expected to have a higher than average rate of absenteeism because of the boredom of the job. I do not excuse absenteeism, job turnover or anything else; it is a fact of life. Post World War II, when the assembly line became a major factor certainly in the manufacturing industry and a major factor in relation to growing numbers of people, these characteristics as percentages of men and women evened out.

The simple situation was that until very recently girls in Australia were very under-educated. I like to think that I am not exactly a greybeard but it was the norm when I was at school for girls to leave school at the age of 13 and not to continue their education. At that age, of course, they were really only basically literate and numerate. They had low job skills. Some of them might have done some short course in business methods. But girls were not educated and were not encouraged to learn skills of a highly sophisticated nature, the sorts of skills that were necessary to get interesting and rewarding jobs. As a consequence, we have had a tradition in employment of women in Australia that women have been crowded into very low skilled unsatisfying jobs-jobs of a very routine nature in the office, jobs of a sometimes very distasteful nature in the factory and jobs of a low satisfaction nature, often in shops. Positions of responsibility were not available to them. Whilst they laboured under a lack of education they also laboured under the handicap of a perception that women were likely to leave their jobs more frequently than men and, therefore, employers did not feel encouraged to train them or to give them advancement.

The assembly line meant that a higher and higher proportion of our total work population and very large numbers of men found themselves in repetitive, uninteresting, dull and unimaginative work. Studies of the assembly line have shown that people in those sorts of jobs do tend to change their jobs frequently and have a higher rate of absenteeism. As I have already stated, industrial sociology under different circumstances has turned up the fact that these characteristics of employees are not in the main confined to women. They are equally exhibited by men. It depends on the nature of the job. That sort of information has been useful as an illustration of the fact that women are not necessarily inferior employees. Many employers have faced that fact. As I said at one stage in my speech last Friday, we have come a long way in Australia in the last 10 years in community attitudes towards women and women's participation . At least to some degree I give credit for that to Australian men. The ethos in Australia of a fair go is one that many men have exhibited towards women. I can certainly speak from my own experience. In 1973 when I was a Senate candidate, a rather young one and the only female Federal parliamentary candidate in Queensland at that stage, I received a lot of encouragement from men who were not associated with any political party, who did not know me for any reason, but who, as I travelled around the State, made the statement: 'We hope you are successful because we think women should be given a go'. They are the actual words that men used to me. It was almost as though I were a female version of the little Aussie battler.

talk.start.para: —That is an Australian tradition to give a person a fair go.

—That is the point I am making. I think that tradition and that part of the Australian ethos has made a major contribution to the advancements and achievements women have made over the last ten years where there has been more awareness of the need. I am making the point that a lot of credit should be given to Australian men for women's advancement as well as to the women who have been working actively in the area. All too often people in the area get so close to it and so excited about it that they tend to give credit where credit is due- because they overlook those sorts of factors, not because they mean to misrepresent the case. Nevertheless, prejudice still exists. Some old attitudes die hard. There are still people who think that women are necessarily inferior employees because they were raised believing that and they have never had presented to them alternative facts. They still have prejudices about employing married women. I do not care if people have a prejudice about employing married women. I care only if the law of this land allows them to inflict that prejudice on other people. I do not care if the former Mayor of Rockhampton, Rex Pilbeam, thought that he should sack a woman because she got married and that he should employ a single person. He would not employ married women, although, I say in juxtaposition, he would be the first to condemn de facto marriages as opposed to official marriages. I do not care that that was his attitude. I care only that he had the right to deprive women of jobs that they held and performed satisfactorily, because he had the power, as well as the right. There was no legal obstacle to his exercising that power. That was his opinion.

speech.para: I really did not care very much that Sir Reginald Ansett did not put quality first in the training and employment of his pilots. I cared as a consumer. For as long as that was Ansett's policy, I travelled Trans Australia Airlines. By that policy, Ansett used criteria other than that the best available person should be in its cockpits as pilots. This is not to say that there were not many excellent pilots in those cockpits, but I was dissatisfied with those criteria. I did not care that Reg Ansett had the view that women should not be in the cockpit. I cared only that he could stop Debbie Wardley from receiving training that she had earned on merit. Not to put too fine a point on it, it must be admitted that not only employers took this attitude in the past. In recent times there was a very celebrated case in Broken Hill. The Barrier Industrial Council took the view that if a girl married she should be dismissed and a single woman employed in her stead; that was the official view. It went to court and was overturned. It was a case very similar to the Rockhampton case in which a girl had been performing her duties perfectly adequately but she married and was sacked, although later reinstated after legal challenge.

The simple fact is that there is still an amount of prejudice in our society. It is sad but it is a hard core. Some of it is probably based on a misconception , and I am fairly hopeful that a conciliatory approach, which is allowed for under this Bill, will enable those sorts of cases to be reasonably, quietly, easily and amicably settled and that we will not have a position of fear and so on. Some people will be genuinely surprised when somebody makes a complaint against them and it is pointed out-I hope fairly gently, if it appears warranted that it be gentle-by a commissioner that that is really not an acceptable standard of behaviour, that we live in a country which is very much for a fair go, for tolerance, for equality and for allowing everybody to have the right to determine his or her destiny according to the rights that other people in the community have.

I am not in the position of a reply speaker, but there are some things to which I wish to reply. There are many things to which I would like to reply but there are some things that I have decided need to be replied to. Some of the things that have been said in the debate are a little sad in that they do not always show an understanding of the subject. We do not have a perfect understanding of any subject that comes before us but some of us have a better understanding than others of some subjects. It is fair to believe that, if people put a point of view that might influence the Senate's opinion and public opinion, they ought to know what they are talking about. That is the reason that I will select what I think are a couple of really outstanding areas that need some sort of reply.

Much reference has been made in debate, not only here but also a great deal in the community and in correspondence that I have received, about women who do not want to work and who are very happy to be a wife and possibly also a mother. I accept that people ought to have that right and I do not believe that this Bill infringes on that right. If it appeared that it did, I for one would be very quick to move because that is of the essence. If a woman decides that her vocation is that of full time mother, she should be as entitled to pursue that vocation as the woman who decides that the vocation she would like to follow is that of a brickie's labourer. We ought to bear in mind that we have that entitlement and the choices are clear. But there are some people who wish to work, who are being prevented from working and who need to work.

A group I just never hear any account taken of by people who get very excited about this other point is the lone parent family. A widow or woman divorcee who was educated at the same time as I was, very undereducated, and who does not have job skills has all sorts of barriers in her way. This is a subject in itself. But I pick out one statistic that passed before me and all other senators very recently because it sums up something that we should be gravely concerned about in Australian society.

One of the sacred cows of politics in Australia is the issue of home ownership; it has been for a very long time. The fact that we have a very high rate of home ownership contributes to the security and stability of individuals and to the standard of living that we all enjoy. There is about a 70 per cent rate of home ownership, which is a statistic of which we have been proud. Yet a table from a report from, I think, the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, in relation to welfare that is available in Australia, shows that of women on the supporting parent's benefit only 12.2 per cent either own their home or are in the process of purchasing a home. That is 12.2 per cent against the national average of 70 per cent. When we hold up home ownership as something so important and fundamental to our society, something is terribly wrong when in that group there is such a low rate of home ownership, something we regard as essential.

It is even worse when one considers that of the men on exactly the same benefit 31.6 per cent are in the position of owning a home or buying a home. It is still tragically low for someone rearing a family to not have the security of home ownership and what that contributes to a family. Nevertheless, the rate is 2 1/2 per cent higher for men than it is for women. That shows a glaring anomaly between the same category of disadvantaged people between the sexes. It also shows a really tragic anomaly in comparison with the rest of society, that nearly 90 per cent of children being reared by mothers on the supporting parent' s benefit are living in accommodation which is rented when we hold up a different standard.

When we look at the class A widow's pension-that is, the widow who is rearing children-we find that the figure for non-home owners is still 64.7 per cent. It is not as bad as the supporting parent figure but it is still tragically the reverse position to the general community position in relation to home ownership . I was surprised by that statistic. I guess I had thought that men insured themselves when they had families, and they certainly insured themselves to pay off mortgages and things like that if they had young families. Very clearly that is not the case when only 35.3 per cent of widows rearing children in Australia are in a position of being home owners or potential home owners.

Many of those sorts of figures can be introduced into the debate. A number of figures have been introduced by others. I picked that one because I think it is so outstandingly at odds with what we consider ourselves to be. I think it is an undeniable indication that something that we like to think is important in our society has tragically gone wrong for one section of it and that there is an enormous discrepancy between men and women in that same catgory. I would like people who are concerned about women who have husbands having the right to stay at home, a right that I support, to turn their eyes and their attention accasionally to that group of people and to consider that.

This Bill has, of course, had broad support from many women's organisations, including women's organisations which are anything but radical. It has had outstanding support from the National Council of Women, from business and professional women and many others. I mention that again to say that there are those who do not cheer at the fact that these women, who by definition are achievers in some way or another, turn their attention to less fortunate women who have been prevented from achieving, but choose instead to sneer and ask: ' Why did these women who have achieved concern themselves?'. It is hypocritical and it is a posturing that has been said about women in this Parliament.

I think it is an incredible line of argument to say that if one is successful in some way, whether it is financially or against what might be perceived as a handicap of sex, one is therefore disqualified from commenting on the obstacles that are met in the process of succeeding and one is disqualified from turning one's attention to those who for one reason or another have not been able to overcome those obstacles. I, for one, will not be blackmailed, bullied or stood over in any way as to my right to comment on women who have not been able to achieve because of discrimination simply because I have achieved. The fact that some women achieve does not mean that there is no discrimination; not at all. The small percentage of women who have achieved, I think, is evidence of the fact that something very different is in hand. I for one cheer groups like business and some professional women who are making the case so clearly and so strongly.

It is also a matter of some bemusement to me that there are those who believe that private individuals ought to have the right to determine another person's destiny and who would be the first to scream blue murder if a government tried to tell people what jobs there were to work in or said: 'This category of job is not open to you because of your sex or your height or the colour of your eyes'. It would be attacked as one of the worst features of socialism. Yet there is, apparently, no logical discrepancy seen there.

I introduce one note because I think it ought to be noted in the conclusion of my speech. In debate a Government senator made a statement about the Liberal Party's spokesman on women, Mr Ian Macphee, which was a very strange statement indeed in relation to this debate. Senator Rosemary Crowley, in reference to the Opposition, said:
They have even left it to a man to be the shadow Minister in charge of women's affairs.

She said that as though it was some sort of negative point against the Liberal Party. I am very proud of Ian Macphee and I think he does an excellent job. I am sure nobody on our side of politics begrudges him his position. It sits very strangely in debate on an anti-discrimination Bill that criticism is attracted because a man is performing that job. I make it very clear that we do not have Ian Macphee for sexist reasons; we have him on the ground on which anybody should be employed in a job; that is, merit.

In conclusion, the Opposition has moved an amendment to the second reading motion. The details of our reasons for this amendment, outlined by Senator Durack when he led for the Opposition on 21 October, are contained in Hansard. I have not reiterated them; I simply wish at the conclusion of the debate to say that the Opposition supports the amendment for the reasons given and will be voting in support of that amendment to the second reading motion.

speech.speaker: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

talker.name: Senator RYAN
talker.role: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women)

talk.start.para: -In closing the second reading stage of the debate on the Sex Discrimination Bill I thank all honourable senators who made a constructive contribution to the debate. In particular, I thank the last speaker, Senator Kathy Martin, who is the Opposition spokesperson on these matters in the Senate although I acknowledge that her colleague, Ian Macphee, has also adopted a most supportive and constructive attitude towards this important piece of legislation. I congratulate Senator Martin for her remarks which were, I think, very important and very pertinent, and in particular I congratulate her for making so lucidly the argument for the support of this legislation by women who themselves have been able to achieve success in this society. It is a point that cannot be made too strongly but certainly Senator Martin made it more lucidly than I have ever heard it made before. Of course it is the case that some women have been able to overcome discrimination in this society and are in the very happy position of not needing, personally, the provisions of this Bill. However, it is more importantly the case, as Senator Martin pointed out, that the majority of women, particularly women on low incomes, are in need of the various protections afforded by this Bill.

speech.para: It has been a very interesting experience for the Government to engage in the process we chose to engage in with regard to this legislation. We recognised, as Senator Martin pointed out, that there is enormous support throughout the community for this legislation, that acknowledgement of the detrimental effects of discrimination is much more widespread than it used to be, that the effects of such discrimination are very long-lasting and that they do require remedies. It has also been very widely recognised, not only by supporters of the Australian Labor Party Government but by people who hold other political philosophies, that governments ought to take whatever steps they can to combat discriminaion. We do not suggest that all discrimination can be dealt with by legislation but we do believe that governments have a responsibility to protect citizens against discimination to the extent that they are able, and this legislation represents our attempt to protect women in particular, although it will also protect men in some circumstances, against blatant discrimination on the grounds of sex, marital status or pregnancy.

Preparation for the Committee stage of this Bill has been very long and I simply place on record again that the Government has entered into extremely thorough and extensive discussions with all people-honourable senators and persons outside the Senate including employers, trade unionists and women's organisations, with all people who sought to take a constructive interest in the Bill and even, I might say, with people whose interest in the Bill was not constructive. We made ourselves open to suggestion and, with our officers, spent an enormous amount of time giving serious consideration to suggestions that came forward for improving the Bill or clarifying its intentions and its operation. As a result, I believe that the Bill is a better and clearer Bill than it would otherwise have been. On the other hand, of course, the Government has attracted some criticism, ironically, because it has entered into this process of negotiation and discussion. Some opponents of the Bill-and there are still some, unfortunately-try to use the fact that we have been open and accessible in terms of our discussion of this Bill as some sort of criticism of the Government. They have pointed to the fact that there are many amendments to this Bill, as if that were a weakness of the Bill, whereas of course it represents in my view the strength that comes about through co-operation and consensus.

Because we anticipate a long Committee stage debate on this Bill and because there has been an enourmous amount of discussion about individual aspects of the Bill, I do not propose to continue the second reading debate. I simply say in conclusion that the Government appreciates all the constructive comments, suggestions and efforts that were made in regard to this legislation. When it is enacted, we will remind the community that it is not only an initiative of government but also an initiative that has attracted the support of the Australian Democrats and of the Liberal Party in this Parliament. We hope that they will share with us our satisfaction that this Government has been able to take this very important step towards eliminating all those kinds of destructive discriminations which have been described so clearly and movingly by my colleagues and by some members of the Opposition and the Australian Democrats throughout the second reading debate.

talker.role: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women)
