Clause 4 (Interpretation)

speech.speaker: Harradine Sen B.

talk.start.para: — by leave-Mr Chairman, I move:

speech.para: (2) Page 3, sub-clause 4 (1), definition of ''de facto spouse'', lines 31 to 34 , leave out the definition.
(3) Page 4, sub-clause 4 (1), definition of ''marital status'', paragraph (f), line 25, leave out the paragraph.

The first amendment seeks to delete the definition of 'de facto spouse'. The second seeks to omit 'marital status', as defined, the de facto spouse of another person. These two amendments are on the same subject matter, and it was for that reason that I sought leave to move them together. The Committee is debating a most important matter because, for the first time in Commonwealth legislation, an attempt is being made to place a de facto relationship on the same level as, or give it the same status as, that of a bone fide married relationship. I say that advisedly because I asked the Parliamentary Library to do a SCALE computer search of Commonwealth legislation and the response of that search of all 20 volumes of Commonwealth law indicates that no similar legislation seeks to place a de facto relationship on the same status level as that of a married relationship-with one exception; that is, the Seamen's War Pensions and Allowances Act 1940. The definition of a de facto given therein is quite distinct from what is contained in the legislation before us. One of my amendments seeks to delete the definition of 'de facto spouse'. Clause 4 (1) of the Sex Discrimination Bill states:

'de facto spouse', in relation to a person, means a person of the opposite sex to the first-mentioned person who lives with the first-mentioned person as the husband or wife of that person on a bone-fide domestic basis although not legally married to that person;

Whilst 'de facto spouse' is not mentioned in the Seamen's War Pensions and Allowances Act, the term 'de facto wife' is. If honourable senators compare the definition in the Sex Discrimination Bill with the definition in that Act they will see what I mean. In the Seamen's War Pensions and Allowances Act the definition of 'de facto wife' states:

'de facto wife', in relation to an Australian mariner, means a woman who, though not legally married to him, has been wholly or substantially maintained by and has lived with the Australian mariner as his wife on a permanent and bona fide domestic basis continuously from a date not less than six months prior to the relevant date and who, at the relevant date- (a) had in her charge a child of the Australian mariner;
(b) was over forty years of age; or
(c) was incapable of supporting herself by reason of her mental or physical incapacity of long standing;

That is the only equivalent provision in legislation. It confers a cash benefit on such a person. Other administrative regulations and the like-for example, the tertiary education assistance scheme regulations, social security administrative decisions and taxation laws-recognise de facto spouses. The difference between those regulations and what is being attempted here is that their purpose is to ensure that de factos do not receive an advantage over a bona fide married couple. I hope members of the Opposition hear this because it is vital to an understanding of it, and I hope I will receive their support. Quite obviously, if such a provision was not taken into account in social security administration decisions de factos could receive two unemployment benefit cheques, for example. The TEAS regulations confer a monetary benefit on a student. This Bill places in Commonwealth legislation for the first time a provision which puts a de facto relationship on the same level as a bona fide married relationship. That might not be too bad, but this provision then forces everyone to accept that fact under pain of being a discriminator. That is the essential difference. I would like the Committee to understand that difference. It is not a question of having and expressing one's views. I believe in the sanctity of marriage and the like, but I am not expressing that belief to justify my opposition to what is contained in this provision. I put to the Committee that the Bill attempts to impose a viewpoint on people and to make them observe that viewpoint under pain of penalty. I will give the example of accommodation. A hotel keeper might wish not to let a room to a de facto couple, one of whom may be his daughter. Clause 23 of the Bill, which deals with accommodation, states:

It is unlawful for a person, whether as principal or agent, to discriminate against another person on the ground of the other person's sex, marital status or pregnancy- (a) by refusing the other person's application for accommodation;
(b) in the terms or conditions on which accommodation is offered to the other person . . .

Marital status is defined as including the de facto spouse of another person. I put that to the Committee for full consideration. The other reason why I believe that the Government and the Opposition should carefully consider this matter is that it is a misinterpretation of the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women. After all, the object of the Bill is to give effect to certain provisions in the Convention. Nothing in the Schedule to the Bill, which is the United Nations Convention, refers to de facto spouses as being on the same basis as married persons. The reason for the absence of such a reference is simple-it was never meant to be there.

talk.start.para: —What about marital status? Is not de facto a kind of marital status?

—I wish to explain this to the Attorney-General. I happened to be in the United Nations as the political adviser from this Parliament in 1977 when the Third Committee was dealing with the drafts of this Convention. I have refreshed my memory and have with me all of the relevant documentation concerning the debate on this matter. I hope the Opposition is listening to this because I have the documentation from the United Nations Third Committee considerations and from the working party. The fact is that the original wording of the clause of this Bill which deals with marital status was 'discrimination against women whether married or unmarried'. Those were the words in the draft that was before the United Nations when I was in New York. Discussions took place-I suppose I am the only one here who knew about this-and subsequent to our leaving, the following, as recorded in the report of the working group of the Committee of the Whole on 6 December 1977, was said:

speech.para: During the discussion which followed, most representatives objected to the use of the words 'married or unmarried', noting that this terminology did not cover all categories of women such as widows, and divorced or separated women.

I would like the Committee to understand that there was no mention whatsoever of de facto relationships in relation to marital status in any of the United Nations Committee's considerations. I hope the Attorney-General will consider this question. If he or his Government is relying on the external affairs power as the constitutional means of requiring adherence to this provision he has another think coming.

talk.start.para: —Was there no recognition of common law marriage?

—No. This is all the documentation which was found after a search. The argument amongst all of those groups, and I must say a disparate lot of people were there from all sorts of nations, some of whom would not have a bar of 'de facto' had it been included-
—But everywhere in the world what we call common law marriage is given the same status. You have to acknowledge that.

—The Attorney-General may not have heard me, but I have mentioned and proven that this is the first time that this status is being recognised at law and being forced down people's throats. It is one thing to recognise it at law-I understand that-but it is another thing entirely to force it down people's throats under pain of penalty.

speech.speaker: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

talker.name: Senator RYAN
talker.role: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women)

talk.start.para: -I would like to clarify what the Sex Discrimination Bill actually does in this respect. Senator Harradine has just suggested that this Bill is saying that de facto marital status is the same as regular marital status. I think that that is a misunderstanding of what the Bill is seeking to do. The Bill is not seeking to say that de facto status is the same as marital status for all purposes; nor is it seeking to say that being divorced is the same as being married, or that being separated is the same as being married or that being single is the same as being married.

speech.para: We are not saying that all these states are the same for all purposes. The Bill says that in the areas covered by it, discrimination on the ground of a person's marital status will be illegal. So discrimination on the ground of a women being single will be illegal. Discrimination on the ground of a woman being married will be illegal. Discrimination on the ground of a woman being in a de facto relationship, for the purposes of this Bill, bearing in mind that there are many exemptions, will be illegal. So I think it is quite wrong and inaccurate of Senator Harradine to claim that the Bill is saying that being in a de facto relationship is the same as being married. Clause 4 of the Bill sets out a number of states which are conventionally understood to be states which can be described as a marital status. The Bill says that people shall not be treated differently according to which marital status they occupy, where it is irrelevant and where it is prohibited by the legislation. Of course, this is not the first time in Commonwealth legislation that there has been a reference to this fact. I have before me the Social Security Act 1947 which defines ' dependent female' in the following terms:
. . . 'dependent female' means a woman who is living with a man (in this Part referred to as her husband) as his wife on a bona fide domestic basis although not legally married to him;
Those are the words of the Social Security Act 1947.

talk.start.para: —That is right, but on a different matter.

—Senator Harradine acknowledged that in regard to the tertiary education assistance scheme. I ask him to consider that a number of statuses in our society are described as marital status. Being divorced is described as a marital status. When one is asked to fill in forms for all sorts of purposes one finds under the heading 'marital status' such sub-headings as 'married', ' divorced', ' never married' and so on. These all come under the heading of marital status. This Bill, in the areas covered by it, provides that a person shall not be treated differently on the ground of being in one status rather than another. Senator Harradine is not suggesting that the Bill says that marriage is the same as divorce or that married person is the same as a widowed person. These are all categories of marital status and the Bill provides that to treat a person less favourably simply on the gounds that they are in one rather than another marital status shall be illegal.

speech.para: Senator Harradine drew attention to the fact that the debate on the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women did not mention de facto status but simply married or unmarried women. It is true that the United Nations Convention is one of the constitutional instruments on which this legislation is based. It is not the only one. There are other constitutional powers on which the legislation is based. Of course the marriage power is a constitutional power which the Commonwealth has regardless of the Convention. It would not be an argument against the inclusion of de facto status for the purposes of the legislation, even if Senator Harradine's interpretation about the debate on the Convention were as he argues it.

I should also point out that if Senator Harradine says the United Nations Convention debate referred to married or unmarried women he really has to make up his mind whether a woman in a de facto status is, according to him, married or unmarried. She must be one or the other. Some people would regard her as being common law married; others would not. Senator Harradine, because of his private beliefs, does not recognise anything other than religious marriage or a state marriage-a legal marriage-but a woman has to be one or the other.

By implication the Convention indeed covered women in de facto relationships, but going beyond that, of course, there are constitutional powers, by which the Government can legislate in these areas, which are separate from the powers it derives under the United Nations Convention. I also point out that the legislation in both New South Wales and South Australia covers de facto status in the definition of marital status. It is not the intention of this Bill-indeed it does not in its definitions state this-that being in a de facto relationship is the same as being in a legally married one. It states that a de facto relationship ought not to be a ground for differential and inferior treatment.

talk.start.para: — The Minister did not address her remarks to the major problem that I pointed out. The major problem is that for the first time in Commonwealth legislation a de facto relationship is being placed on the same level as a married relationship. This legislation forces every citizen of Australia to accept that fact under pain of penalty. It is all very well for the Minister to say that the Bill does not say that a de facto relationship is the same as a married relationship. I refer honourable senators to another example- page 16, clause 24, relating to land. If one of us who were fortunate enough to own an additional home placed a 'to let' notice in the paper and received an application from a de facto couple, would the decision to deny that couple the right to live in that home be discrimination? Of course it would be discrimination.
—You would accept a single person living with another person.
—No, I would not.
—Would you deny that under this Bill? You would be discriminating.

—That is another matter I want to turn to when we refer to land, bearing in mind certain legal advice that I have received on that aspect. I ask honourable senators to wait until we turn to the matter of land. Would a hotel keeper be liable to action under this Bill for discriminating against a couple in the circumstances that I previously described? The answer, quite obviously, is yes. I see the Minister nodding her head. Is that right?
—That is right.

—I ask the Committee to consider that question. What we are doing in passing this legislation is placing a de facto relationship on the same status and level as a bona fide married relationship. That is one matter but we are also forcing people to observe that. This gives me some ammunition for an argument for conscientious objection under this legislation. I return to the point that I made before. I admitted that, for social security, taxation, the tertiary education assistance scheme and the like, of course a de facto relationship is recognised because a benefit is being conferred. We do not have to cop the views of other people about de facto relationships having the same status as married relationships in such circumstances. That is no concern of ours. However, it is under this legislation. The Opposition and the Australian Democrats should think seriously when this matter is voted upon.

speech.speaker: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

talker.name: Senator RYAN
talker.role: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women)

talk.start.para: -I repeat that the inclusion of de factor status as a marital status along with single, separated and divorced, does not change that status legally. The Sex Discrimination Bill does not legalise a defacto relationship. What it does is require that people in a de facto relationship shall not be treated differently from people in a different marital relationship for the purposes described under this legislation. Senator Harradine is quite right when he says that if a person has a house to let he or she should not use the marital status of an applicant for that accommodation as a ground for treating that applicant less favourably than he or she would an applicant of another marital status. That is what the Bill is about.

speech.para: If a person sets up a business, the marital status of a client is not relevant in most cases. Similarly in the example that Senator Harradine used of a hotel owner in the business of letting accommodation. The access of a person to that service should not be determined by that person's marital status. It is quite a different matter to take a lodger into the home, it is quite a different matter for people in a group house who would be living with the tenant. There are exemptions to that to which Senator Harradine might like to address his attention. But in relation to a commercial enterprise-a house to let or rooms to let in an hotel-the legislation says that it is not right to refuse a person commercial service on the grounds of the marital status of the person applying. That is the intention of the Bill. It is not the business of someone letting property or someone renting rooms in a hotel to concern himself or herself with the marital status of the person involved. Under those circumstances it is discriminatory to treat less favourably a person simply on the grounds of his or her marital status.

This Bill does not alter a person's right to hold a view about marriage or about people who live in de facto relationships. Such views can be held. I think that Senator Martin put very clearly tonight the distinction between people being able to hold a view about marriage and people being able to deny unfairly a good or a service to that person. Perhaps it will help Senator Harradine if I remind him of the provisions of the Racial Discriminaion Act. That Act does not require people to say that a person of one race is the same as a person of another race. A person of the Aboriginal race is not the same as a person of the European race. The legislation says that a person of the Aboriginal race shall not be treated differently from or less favourably than a person of the European race. It is a question of establishing the rights of people to certain publicly provided goods and services.

It is the view of our Government that in the areas covered by the legislation those rights should not be eroded because of a person's marital status. So if somebody is running a hotel business marital status ought not to be grounds for treating a customer less favourably than he would otherwise be treated. I simply repeat-and I hope that Senator Harradine can accept this-that the Bill does not change de facto status. It does not legalise it. It does not say that it is the same as marital status. It does not affect anybody's right-Senator Harradine's or anyone else's-to hold his private, personal views about marriage and the status of people who are not married. It simply says that in regard to certain publicly provided goods and services marital status-be it de facto, separated, divorced or married-should not be used as a reason for treating a person less favourably than he would otherwise be treated.

talk.start.para: —I ask Senator Harradine whether his-
—Senator Harradine is not the Minister.
—Mr Chairman, may I ask Senator Harradine whether in his opinion the amendment he is to move later on the basis of his conscientious objections covers this matter?

speech.speaker: Harradine Sen B.

talk.start.para: — As Senator Ryan said, Mr Chairman, I am not the Minister--
—At least not the same as the Minister, in any respect.
—We are dealing with sex discrimination and not with sex.

—Senator Ryan is a bit sharper than I am, I think. Mr Chairman , I have tried to explain the situation. I do not want to canvass what I have already said. I think we are dealing with two different aspects. I think that we understand what is happening. I am of the view that people who hold a view about marriage should not be forced under penalty-as is the case under this legislation-to, in effect, hold another view. I think that one of the most devastating statements made by the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs ( Senator Ryan) tonight was: 'If I am right as far as the external affairs power is concerned, the question of having a de facto spouse as part of the definition of marital status can rely on the marriage power'. I think that is a most devastating statement.

speech.para: Amendment negatived.

speech.speaker: Harradine Sen B.

talk.start.para: —I have a question for the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) in regard to line 30 on page 5 of the Sex Discrimination Bill (No. 2) 1983. I preface this question with a reference to the symposium on statutory interpretation. I refer to comments made by the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) in his paper entitled 'Extrinsic Aids to Statutory Interpretation'. I would like the Minister to answer a couple of questions, bearing in mind that, as the Attorney-General said in his statement, the Government is preparing legislation on extrinsic aids to the interpretation and administration of the law. As to voluntary bodies, the definition in clause 4 states:

speech.para: 'voluntary body' means an association or other body (whether incorporated or unincorporated) the activities of which are not engaged in for the purpose of making a profit, but does not include- (a) a club;
(b) a registered organization;
this is where my question lies-
a body established by a law of the Commonwealth, of a State or of a Territory.

Is a political party such as the Australian Labor Party, the Liberal Party of Australia or the National Party of Australia a voluntary body and thus exempt under clause 34 from the operation of Divisions 1 and 2 in certain respects?

talker.name: Senator RYAN
talker.role: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women)

talk.start.para: -The officers are considering this matter, but I would consider that a political party would be a voluntary body. I am not aware of any legislative process that one needs to undertake and, therefore, it would not be covered for the purposes of this legislation.
— Will the Minister give an assurance that churches in Canberra that are incorporated under ordinance for certain purposes remain, nonetheless, voluntary bodies for the purposes of the Bill?

speech.speaker: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

talker.name: Senator RYAN
talker.role: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women)

talk.start.para: -Yes, I give that assurance, because there is a special exemption for religious bodies that would make it particularly clear that they would be exempted.

speech.para: Clause agreed to.
Clauses 5 and 6-by leave-taken together.

speech.speaker: Martin Sen K.J.

talk.start.para: —by leave-I move:

speech.para: (1) Page 6, sub-clause 5 (1), line 13, at end of sub-clause, add 'and the less favourable treatment is not reasonable in the circumstances'.
(2) Page 6, sub-clause 6 (1), line 36 at end of sub-clause, add 'and the less favourable treatment is not reasonable in the circumstances'.

The Opposition has grouped these amendments together, as it will be grouping together other Opposition amendments, in the interests of brevity, where wordiness is not necessary. The first amendment is an amendment to sub-clause 5 (1). Clause 5 outlaws discrimination on the basis of sex. Clause 6 outlaws discrimination on the ground of marital status. The amendments are identically worded. They contain words that are contained in clause 7, which relates to discrimination on the ground of pregnancy. Clause 5 states:
For the purposes of this Act, a person . . . discriminates against another person . . .on the ground of the sex of the aggrieved person if, by reason of-
(a) the sex of the aggrieved person;
(b) a characteristic that appertains generally to persons of the sex of the aggrieved person; or
(c) a characteristic that is generally imputed to persons of the sex of the aggrieved person,

the discriminator treats the aggrieved person less favourable than, in circumstances that are the same or are not materially different, the discriminator treats or would treat a person of the opposite sex.
To that clause we seek to add the words:
and the less favourable treatment is not reasonable in the circumstances.

I point out that the wording of clauses 5, 6 and 7 is identical to all intents and purposes except that they deal with sex, marital status and pregnancy respectively. However, in clause 7, the Government has the words 'the less favourable treatment is not reasonable in the circumstances' in the same position as the Opposition seeks to place them in clauses 5 and 6. The Government apparently accepts that discrimination on the grounds of pregnancy or a characteristic that is generally imputed to persons who are pregnant can be justified on the grounds of reasonableness in certain circumstances. The Opposition suggests that the same could apply in the case of sex and marital status.

I emphasise that it is not the Opposition's intention by introducing these amendments to negate the purpose of the Bill. That is not the Opposition's intention at all. However, I turned to the explanatory notes for some guidance why the words were contained in clause 7 at all. I found no explanation. I found repeated the words 'the less favourable treatment is not reasonable in the circumstances'. But we have not had an explanation of reasonableness. I can see some circumstances-very few, I must admit-where it would be 'reasonable in the circumstances'. I think I can also see some cases where 'less favourable treatment' would be reasonable in very particular circumstances in relation to sex and marital status.

talk.start.para: —What sorts of examples do you have in mind?

—I can give some examples and I intend to do so, but I will develop my own case. One real concern of people in the community in relation to the sex discrimination legislation-I find amazing the passions it stirs-is that fears are genuinely held that either people will be hauled off to the Human Rights Commission because they do not realise they are doing the wrong thing as they really mean well-and this applies particularly in the harassment area-or that there are cases where sex or marital status is a real factor. I admit that the Bill allows for specific cases. There is a fear on the part of a number of people that we will get into a situation of ridiculousness, of unfairness- something might be considered unfair by community standards-while accepting the notion of equality.

speech.para: The areas covered by discrimination are difficult areas with which to deal. It is probably a little easier to deal with marital status. I would accept that there are characteristics that appertain generally to a person of a particular marital status. There are characteristics that appertain to a person of a particular sex just as there are some that appertain to pregnancy. There are specific characteristics which can be a factor, for example, in the area of employment. An employer might have a very good reason, for example, when interviewing applicants for a job to have some particular concerns about somebody who is married. Provided that the employer asks the same questions of a married male applicant as he or she asks of a married female applicant-in other words, there is no sexual discrimination or weighting of someone's marital status, the details of which might affect considerations of the employer-and they are treated equally, I think that that would be fair. It could be a major consideration-

talk.start.para: —I just do not see how the marital status of somebody is relevant to that person's state of mind.

—It can matter very much. There can be jobs that involve a training program for something that is specific to those jobs. That training might continue over a period. If I were a married woman applying for a job which required such training and by virtue of the fact that I was married certain other things follow, it would not be unreasonable, where that is a factor in the job, to be asked some questions by a potential employer-the employer would be expending resources on me by way of training and employment-about my husband's employment. He could ask, for example, whether my husband worked for the foreign service and if so whether he was likely to be transferred in six months time. The training period could extend over two years. It could be that the fact that somebody is married is a factor. The fact that somebody is married is not enough ; further questions would have to be asked. For example, the question would have to be asked: 'If your husband is transferred would you resign from this job in order to accompany him?' There are certain assumptions that cannot be made, but there would be circumstances in which my characteristics as an employee would be affected by the fact, first, that I am married and secondly that I have certain attitudes towards my marital relationship which would mean that if my husband was transferred in the course of his employment I would choose to move with him rather than stay where I was and continue employment in that job.
—But you would expect that to be asked of a married man too, presumably?

—I said that. I said provided the same conditions are put on male and female applicants. The conditions should obtain generally to marital status. If a man applied for a job and, as can happen, his wife were a member of the foreign service-we have women in the foreign service who are married and subject to transfer-that could be a similar consideration for a potential employer. I do not want to labour the point too much. What I am saying is that provided the words 'and the less favourable treatment is not reasonable in the circumstances' are inserted in the clause the test of reasonableness is applied and the test of particular circumstances is applied. We are not then giving people an entitlement to discriminate on the grounds of prejudice, watonness, personal preference or even hunches. The discrimination must be for a specific reason. It would have to be meted out equally to men and women and it is a reasonable type of qualification to put on employment just as is pregnancy. I am sure that the Government does not mean, in putting that qualification on pregnancy, to give anyone a wholesale let-out. It would mean it to be just what it says, 'not reasonable in the circumstances'. They are two tests that would have to be put in relation to pregnancy which I think are as reasonable in other circumstances, namely, the circumstances of sex and marital status.

—I just put to Senator Martin a possible situation, because it seems to me that what she said did not entirely link up with the insertion in clause 5 of the words 'and the less favourable treatment is not reasonable in the circumstances'. I put it to Senator Martin that the circumstances could be such that the job that is being offered requires some training but the best training would be that which is done overseas or interstate. It might be proposed that a person in a marital state does the training in Australia or in the State in which that person lives. That might be the alternative, but it would be 'reasonable in the circumstances'. The training might be less comprehensive but because that person has marital status and would otherwise be separated from her husband and she was given training in Australia rather than being sent overseas, it might be said then that this is 'reasonable in the circumstances', although it would certainly be less favourable treatment not to send her away. Is that something which the honourable senator has in mind ? It seems to me that that is the situation which would be covered by the insertion of the words proposed to be inserted in relation to marital status.

—I do not want to prolong the debate but I think Senator Missen misunderstood what I was talking about. I think he has taken two elements of the position that I described and merged them into one. I do not really think the question he was asking was relevant to my particular example. I was talking about someone, say, who is married to a diplomat and who applies for a job in Canberra with a private employer in which an important amount of training is involved. The employer might think it quite reasonable to expect some return from the trained person. I am not suggesting that training is available as it may not be; it may be quite specific to that enterprise. If the spouse of that person, whether that person is a man or a woman, is subject to transfer that would not make that person a desirable employee.
—I understand your example but I am putting to you a different example which I suggest more practically fits your clause, that is all.
—Senator Ryan is about to reply. Perhaps Senator Missen can come and explain his example in a little more length.

speech.speaker: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

talker.name: Senator RYAN
talker.role: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women)

talk.start.para: -The Government will not accept the two amendments just moved by Senator Martin- not because we do not consider that she is addressing a serious issue but because we do not believe that it is necessary to accept those amendments. Let me explain. The Government is not prepared to accept the 'reasonable in the circumstances' addition because it would imply that treating people differently on the basis of their sex is prima facie reasonable and that it is up to the person who objects to prove that it is not reasonable in the circumstances. The Government has included, as Senator Martin has acknowledged, a number of exemptions throughout the Bill, particularly in the employment area where discrimination on the grounds of sex or marital status would be reasonable. Those exemptions are there and we believe it is a fair and reasonable list of exemptions.

speech.para: Of course, with regard to pregnancy, we considered that it was important to include the 'which is not reasonable' addition because, in addition to areas where exemptions are provided, there are other situations where it would not be possible to spell out the facts with precision because of the different stages of pregnancy and the situation in which it may or may not be reasonable to take it into account. For example, if a woman were seven months pregnant, applied for a job and the employer wanted a person to work on a six months project, it would be reasonable for the employer to refuse employment to that person because she would not be available for the length of time required. But a similar refusal may not be reasonable if the woman were two months pregnant and would be available for six months. Because there are so many different circumstances and conditions, we judged it appropriate to include circumstances where it may be reasonable.

I would like to address myself to Senator Martin's example of an employer seeking information regarding the marital status of an applicant because training over a long period is involved. It is not the intention of the Bill that an employer should be forced to employ a person who will not be available over a period or who will not be available to work to return the investment made in training that person. But the criterion should not be the marital status of a person but the availability of a person. Therefore, it would be perfectly proper and, indeed, sensible for an employer to say: 'Well, this job involves a one- year training period and then we expect that you will be available for five years'. If, in response to that, the applicant says: 'Well, I cannot give you that assurance because I am married to a diplomat and I expect that he or she will be posted overseas', it would not be discriminatory in terms of this Bill for the employer to say that that applicant cannot have the job. The point I am making is that it is not the marital status of the person that is at issue, although that turns out to be the reason for the lack of availability; it is the lack of availability that makes that person unsuitable. The example that Senator Martin gave is just one example but people in other sorts of relationships- indeed, Senator Harradine, de facto relationships-may similarly be unavailable because they do not wish to travel.

talk.start.para: —Me?
—Senator Harradine may disagree or disapprove, but it happens to be a fact of life--
—I thought you might mean that I was in a de facto relationship.

—I would never dream of suggesting such a thing to Senator Harradine, but it is a fact of life that some persons in our society are in de facto relationships and for those reasons, because of their desire to travel with or accompany a partner, may not be available. What is at issue is not whether they are married or in a de facto relationship. Indeed, they could have some other family responsibility which would prevent their travelling or require them to travel in a way that would make them unsuitable applicants. What is at issue is the availability to fulfil the terms of employment. If the employment requires training, if it requires a certain number of years work in a certain place and the person applying for the job cannot give those assurances, the employer is under no obligation to employ that person even if the lack of availability is explained in terms of the person's marital relationship. It is the lack of availability, not the marital status, which is at issue. There is no intention in this Bill for an employer to employ a person who, for whatever reason, would not be available for the term and conditions of the employment.

speech.speaker: Lewis Sen A.W.R

talk.start.para: —I raise with the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women ( Senator Ryan) the problems for employees' marriages as a result of what I call compulsory close cohabitation. For example, a driver working for a long distance trucking organisation who is required to drive, perhaps, from Melbourne to Perth and back with great regularity and who necessarily sleeps in the vehicle while it is moving or spending--
—Not while he is driving, I hope.

—I wish Senator Haines would not make these stupid, infantile interjections, Mr Chairman. From time to time one driver sleeps in the truck while another one continues to drive or alternatively the vehicle is stopped while the drivers have their compulsory break. It concerns me that if, as a result of their employment provisions, one of those drivers is male and the other one is female and they are required by the employer to share that job, that may perhaps create complication for them, but the thing that worries me--
—What sort of complications?
—I suggest to the Minister that she is totally naive if she does not believe that two people sharing such a job and staying at various places overnight might not develop a very close relationship.
—What is the problem?
—Senator Giles said: 'What is the difficulty? What is the problem? ' The problem is that the wife or the husband left behind might very well be unhappy about that.
—What has that to do with the Bill?
—Because the employer wants to stop that problem before it starts.

—Exactly, as my colleague Senator Crichton-Browne quite rightly points out to Senator Tate across the chamber, Senator Tate does not seem to be able to see any difficulty either. The employer might very well want to stop such a complication happening before it commences.
—Ha!

—Senator Crowley thinks it is humorous. I assure Senator Crowley that if she were a truck driver instead of a senator she might find it is a very difficult complication to have to put up with. If she were a spouse left at home while her husband went off driving around the nation with a woman co-driver there would be no doubt that she would be concerned about the future of her marriage. I think that the outbursts by the women sitting on the Government benches--
—And Senator Tate.
—And Senator Tate, are such that the people of Australia ought to understand that they really have no idea of what happens in real life.
—That is right.
—They have no idea at all, do they, Senator Harradine?
—Perhaps they do not understand what might happen in a stable marriage.

—Or, as Senator Walters says, perhaps they do not understand what might happen in a stable marriage. Of course, the truth of the situation is that any marriage, throughout its course, runs into problems and it is up to the partners to avoid difficulties and complications. That is one way marriages survive. I ask the Minister, seriously-I expect to receive a proper answer and will pursue it until I do-what she would say to an employer who is forced into the situation of having a topnotch driver, male or female, and of having to employ a person of the other sex as a co-driver. His topnotch driver may come to him and say: 'Look, if you force me to be a driver with the other person my marriage will be at risk and you will force me to leave your employment'. What is an employer to do in those circumstances? Senator Giles is giggling away; Senator Crowley is hiding her mouth behind her hand as if this is some terrible suggestion. The Minister thinks it is very humorous. I hope the people of Australia realise that these people, who are pushing this Bill through the Parliament, have no idea of, and have not thought through, this problem. It would be a massive problem and I expect the Minister to tell the Committee why it would be reasonable to foist upon an employer such an employee in those circumstances. That is why the Opposition has put forward this amendment, which provides . . .

speech.para: 'and the less favourable treatment is not reasonable in the circumstances'.

The Minister and the Government seem to understand that it is reasonable when the discrimination is on the ground of pregnancy. I suggest to the Minister that it is a reasonable addition on the other two grounds also.

speech.speaker: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

talker.name: Senator RYAN
talker.role: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women)

talk.start.para: -I will address myself seriously to Senator Lewis's point. First of all, it is a fact of Australian working life that men and women work closely together in a whole number of areas. I do not know of any men and women who co-drive trucks but certainly men and women do work closely together in a whole range of areas. They have learned to do so maturely and responsibly. There are men and women in the Senate and we spend a great deal of time in each other's company-too much time, as far as some of us are concerned. Indeed on occasion we have been in this chamber until the early hours of the morning and some people have even gone off to sleep. I hope that that has not caused marital trauma for the spouses of those honourable senators who are married. It is quite offensive to suggest that adult people cannot work together in a close environment, if that is required by the work, without inevitably getting into a situation that might result in marital problems for those who are married.

speech.para: However, I do point out that the Sex Discrimination Bill does provide exemptions as far as accommodation is concerned, and I draw Senator Lewis's attention to clause 30 (2) and in particular paragraph (f), which states that if it is not reasonable for the employer to provide separate sleeping accommodation and sanitary facilities for persons of either sex they are to be exempted. So if it were the case that two drivers had to sleep in a truck-that that was the accommodation provided-the employer would be exempted. If it were not possible to provide other, separate accommodation that circumstance would be exempted from the operation of the Bill. So Senator Lewis can rest assured that the marriages of truck drivers, male or female, will not be threatened by the enactment of this legislation.

speech.speaker: Lewis Sen A.W.R

talk.start.para: —I assure the Minister that I was aware of clause 30. I presume that now I can say to my shearing mates down in the Western District that they can relax because this exemption in regard to accommodation will mean that shearing contractors will not be forced to employ women. I was aware of that also in regard to people working for the Country Roads Board of Victoria who live in caravans on a site for weeks at a time. I appreciated that those workers would not have women foisted upon them. Some of them will not thank me for that. Nevertheless, that fails to face up to the reality that there are circumstances in life when two people may be pushed together and may have to work in very close proximity to each other. It is not a question of whether they develop a sexual relationship. I did not suggest that that was the case. I chose my words very carefully. I said that they will probably develop a very close relationship. For example, employees of Telecom Australia frequently work underground, repairing or altering telephone cables. Two people working underground or around a Telecom pole, trying to fix terminals, are working in very close proximity. I suggest to the Committee that that also could create difficulties in the home of one or other of them if the spouse of one of them thinks that there is a risk to his or her marriage because of those people working so closely together. I understand that if a person's marriage breaks up and that person does not worry about such things, of course it may be a laughing matter, but if one is concerned about trying to keep a marriage stable, one must look at these things.

speech.para: Senator Ryan mentioned the fact that we work together in this chamber. One would not think that there would be anything going on in this chamber. However, one observes that some things do go on from time to time. Nevertheless, in this building the Minister would be aware that great difficulties have been created by close proximity working relationship between men and women. Frequently, marriages of members of parliament and of staff have broken up as a result purely and simply of the close proximity of the couples working together. A sexual relationship may not necessarily develop. I have tried to explain to the Minister, but she apparently does not seem to be able to grasp it, that a wife who is at home caring for three or four children, trying to get them off to school and trying to keep them clean, is aware that her husband is at work surrounded by glamorous women who may very well be endeavouring to use their guile to woo him in some way. It is a matter of grave concern to many women in this country that their husbands may in some way be subjected to improper influences. It is a fact of life that that happens, and it is one of the causes for the break up of such marriages.

All I am suggesting to the Minister is that if an employer can see that a difficult situation might arise as a result of such circumstances, and if he can establish that it is reasonable in all the circumstances to discriminate, he ought to be entitled to make that discrimination. It may very well be a discrimination in favour of women. There are many circumstances where one could imagine that that might arise. I am not suggesting that it must be a discrimination in some way supportive of the male. It may very well be a discrimination against the male. Nevertheless, if an astute employer is able to see that a stupid situation could or would arise and is able to nip it in the bud-the Australian Labor Party ought to take account of nipping things in the bud-he ought to be given that power, even if he has to appear before the Human Rights Commission and establish why he is exercising that discrimination.

speech.speaker: Harradine Sen B.

talk.start.para: — Mr Chairman, I support the Opposition's amendment to these clauses. This amendment is to provide protection against sex discrimination and discrimination on the grounds of marital status, a requirement which is in the form of 'the less favourable treatment is not reasonable in the circumstances'. The same requirement is contained in clause 7 (1) (b), which is headed 'Discrimination on the ground of pregnancy'. It just so happens that that is the case. I believe that amendment is an eminently reasonable proposition. The test should in fact be whether the less favourable treatment was reasonable in the circumstances. Let me give honourable senators an example. Say a superintendent of the traffic police refuses to place a policewoman on the night shift patrol on a 1000cc BMW. The reason for that is that on the day shift the traffic police patrol the roads in twos or threes and know where each other is, but at a particular hour of the night or early morning the policeman or the policewoman may be required to attend an accident at which the 1000cc BMW falls over. It would be virtually impossible for the policewoman to pick the BMW up.
—Oh, rubbish.

—Senator Giles says: 'Oh, rubbish'. We are talking about the average policewoman. Some of them I know are quite petite and it is almost a pleasure to be booked by them. But we are talking in a serious vein whereby a superintendent says that he cannot have a policewoman on the night shift. Under this legislation that is clearly discrimination on the grounds of her sex, but everyone in this Committee would agree that what the superintendent is doing is really protecting that policewoman. He is discriminating against her or for her, whichever way one likes. But if she feels that it is less favourable treatment, he can, as the discriminator, place before the Sex Discrimination Commissioner or the Human Rights Commission a defence for his action that the less favourable treatment is not reasonable in the circumstances. The example I have just given of the police superintendent could apply in this city of Canberra.

speech.para: I believe, because of further matters that we will be discussing later in this Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 (No. 2), which refer to the rather wide ranging powers of the Human Rights Commission and of the Sex Discrimination Commissioner , it is important for a sense of reasonableness to be brought into these two clauses. That is why I support the Opposition's proposal. The spokesperson for the Opposition, Senator Martin, indicated that this amendment was not designed to upset the general thrust of anti-discrimination legislation. Of course it is not. It is simply placing in these clauses a definition similar to that contained in clause 7 (1) (b)-'the less favourable treatment is not reasonable in the circumstances'-which has been included by the Government.

talk.start.para: —I would like to ask the Minister a question about another example that would apply to the Opposition's amendment. Consider the situation in which an employer is forced to retrench two women. The same argument would apply if he were employing two women. Should not that employer take into account the social situation of those women? Say that one of the women is married and her husband has a very good job with the same employer. Consequently that woman does not really need the job from a financial point of view. Say that the other woman is a single mother or a supporting mother with two or three children and in great need. She could be desperately in need of the job. Would the employer be discriminating if he were to say: 'Well, I am sorry. Because you are married and you have financial security I intend to keep on the supporting mother who is in desperate need of this job'. He could be making his decision solely on the ground of marital status. He could be discriminating in favour of a single woman who is greatly in need of financial assistance or who is not as secure financially as a married woman or a woman who is in a de facto relationship. Can the Minister comment on that situation?

—I rise very briefly. I do not seek to extend the debate. I stated the Opposition's view when I spoke to the amendment. I say to the Minister in relation to her reply and the debate which has followed that we are certainly aware of the provisions of clause 30 (2) which spells out a number of exemptions. I think it is reasonable to say that one cannot believe that any Bill covers all positions. There may be cases that are not covered. I reiterate that we believe that our test is reasonable. It is not meant as any support for sexual discrimination. Obviously, from the debate that has ensued, people have very wide, broad and differing ideas on what is justifiable discrimination. Under those circumstances I think the Minister should recognise at least some of the apprehensions that are abroad in the community and that the test of reasonableness and the test of circumstances are more likely to lead to a happier acceptance of the legislation in the community. I do not seek to continue to promote the Opposition's view. I have stated it and I recognise what the Minister has said in her reply. I just point out that we believe it is not a total reply in relation to this Bill.

—I want to take up for a moment the proposition put by Senator Lewis which attracted a considerable amount of mirth from honourable senators on the other side of the chamber. I think the amendment seeks to introduce a sense of reasonableness into this legislation. I cannot see that in any way it distorts or dilutes the general thrust of the good intentions of the provision. It provides a practical mechanism for overcoming the anomalies that can arise from time to time. The Antarctic Division of the Department of Science and Technology is one division that takes a great deal of care in screening and interviewing applicants before they go to the Antarctic. It takes into consideration all the matters that have been raised by Senator Lewis. Half the people who go to the Antarctic are not male and the other half female. There are very good reasons for the determinations that that Division makes. The men have to work in harmony with the women. It has to be recognised by the Department that there has to be harmony on behalf of the total family and that the married men who go to the Antarctic work in harmony with the single women. With respect to industrial relations generally any employer should be entitled to consider, when he or she makes his judgment, whether it is likely to disrupt his business or whether it is likely to disrupt the harmony and the smooth functioning of his industry. I do not know what the present circumstances are. But there was a time when there were only men on drilling rigs, not because of discrimination against women in the general sense but because it was found in those days that, because of the long periods the men spent at sea by themselves it was disruptive to them, to the company and to their productivity in some cases. I think that is a position that is taken in some cases by some of the--
—It would solve a lot of problems if there were only women on oil rigs, wouldn't it?

—There is no problem with that at all providing the women can do all the jobs required of them and if it were proved that to have men on board would disrupt the smooth functioning and harmony of the rig. I do not see that as a problem at all. I conclude by asking the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) a simple question. She has said that this is not really related to sex. It is one's capacity to fulfil the functions in the time required that gives the employer the reward. I ask: Is it discriminating to ask a person-very obviously a female-whether she is married? When the answer is yes, is it discriminatory to ask her whether she is planning to have a family in the near future? The Minister has put this on the basis that she might volunteer that information. I ask the Minister whether it is discriminatory to ask her whether she is married with the intention of asking her whether she is likely to have a family in the near future. To do so would enable the employer to make a decision whether to spend time giving her adequate training and also whether the employer would receive adequate reward for his outlay, his expenditure and his training of the employee.

speech.speaker: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

talker.name: Senator RYAN
talker.role: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women)

talk.start.para: —A number of points have been raised which I will address. First of all, Senator Harradine raised the question of policewomen doing night duty. He suggested that it would be unsuitable for policewomen to do that because particular policewomen might not be strong enough to pick up a BMW 1000 motor- bike. I point out to Senator Harradine that, where strength is a criterion for the performance of a job, an employer is not required to employ somebody who does not have that strength. So if the duties of a particular area of the police force require a level of strength which no policewoman has, she would not be required to be employed in that occupation. If it is a strength test some policewomen may pass it and some policewomen may not. I certainly would not be able to pick up a BMW 1000cc. But I suppose there might be men in--
—You are being modest.

—I know my strengths and I know my weaknesses. I ask honourable senators to consider that we are not requiring employers to employ people who do not have the inherent capacity to do the job, be it physical strength, qualifications or experience. What we are saying is that irrelevant criteria, such as a person's marital status or sex, should not be used. Clearly it is relevant for police officers doing night duty to have certain characteristics including, I would think, physical strength. So it is perfectly in order for applicants for those jobs to be tested to see whether they have those characteristics. If they do not have the characteristics, they are not entitled to the job; if they do have the characteristics they are entitled to the job. I ask Senator Harradine to consider that.

speech.para: Senator Walters raised the question of an employer who may have to choose between two women prospective employees, one who is able to be supported by her spouse and another who is supporting dependants alone. There is nothing in this legislation to prevent an employer from giving the job to the woman with dependants. Having dependants is not a ground specified in the legislation as being irrelevant to employment. So if an employer wants to take into account the fact that a certain prospective employee has dependants, he or she is perfectly free to do so and perfectly free to offer the job to that person.

Senator Martin agreed that there were exemptions in the legislation and pointed out, rightly, that the list of exemptions is not inclusive. We have acknowledged that. I ask Senator Martin to note that under clause 30 (2) (h) regulations can be made to prescribe more positions. We expect that that will happen on a fairly continual basis during the early months of the operation of the legislation. We certainly could not think of all possible exemptions. It has been the experience in those States where the legislation is in place that further areas can be prescribed as necessary. I persist with the Government's view that, while not arguing with what Senator Martin is trying to achieve by her amendments, the amendments are not necessary and could be deleterious in some cases because they would force the applicant to show that the discrimination was not reasonable and they imply a prima facie acceptance that the discrimination is reasonable in circumstances other than the kinds of circumstances which we have exempted.

Senator Crichton-Browne asked again whether an employer should be able to ask about the marital status of the applicant and her intentions with regard to having children. I simply reiterate that it is not a question of what family plans a person has. What an employer must and should ask concerns the availability of the person for the job over a long period. If a female prospective employee intends to start a family within the next two years, I believe that she should say that.

talk.start.para: —What if she doesn't?

—If she does not, she is being dishonest, but she is being dishonest in the same way as a male who applies for a job knowing that he has every intention of going overseas in six months time but says to the employer: ' Oh, yes, I will be available for two years'. If applicants are going to be dishonest-it is a highly undesirable thing-we cannot control that through this legislation. But I think it is entirely reasonable for an employer to question a prospective employee about his or her availability. If in answer to that a prospective employee says 'Well, I can give you assurances about my availability only for six months because after that I intend to start a family', the employer would not be prevented under this legislation from saying: 'Well, you are not going to be available for the period I want you to be available; therefore, you don't get the job'. Again, I repeat it is availability for the job and the inherent capability to perform the job and not the prospective employee's intentions with regard to her family that ought to be taken into account. I contend that by requiring employers to look at the availability or the capacity of the person to perform the job we will not be intruding in any way on the legitimate rights of employers.

—I think the Minister just probably did not understand the question I asked her. I said: If the employer decided to employ a single woman and not a married woman because she had financial security, would that be discriminating against the married woman because of her marital status?

talker.name: Senator RYAN
talker.role: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women)

talk.start.para: —Senator Walters first asked the question in terms of a woman with dependent children--
—If you read Hansard, you will see that I then said 'or perhaps not even with any dependants but a single woman'.
—There is nothing to stop the employer taking into account either the dependants that a woman has to support or her capacity to be dependent on another person.
—Answer the question.

—It is important to recognise that Senator Walters is asking about dependants and not about marital status, although she describes it in terms of marital status. At issue here is how an employer decides between two people. There is nothing to prevent the employer favouring a prospective employee with dependants, be they children, dependent aged parents or an invalid spouse.

— The Minister still is not answering the question I asked. It is terribly important. It is crucial to the Bill, and to our understanding of the Bill. Can an employer say to a woman: 'Are you married and is your husband in employment because the woman I have seen previously needs the job financially and I will employ her if you are financially secure'? In my opinion, according to this Bill, that discriminates against a woman who is financially secure because of her marital status. Again I ask the Minister: Is an employer entitled to discriminate against a woman in regard to her marital status because her husband is employed and she is financially secure in favour of a single woman who is not financially secure and who perhaps desperately needs the job because of that financial situation? The same applies to retrenchment.

talker.name: Senator RYAN
talker.role: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women)

talk.start.para: —It will be illegal for the employer to discriminate simply on the grounds of marital status. It would not be illegal for the employer to take into account the prospective employees' capacity to support themselves or be supported. The employer could take into account the circumstances of the applicant, but it would be illegal to discriminate simply on the ground of marital status. That is what it is about.

—The Minister referred to clause 30 (2) (h) in relation to the regulations. Does the Minister agree with me that that clause would not allow the Minister to make a regulation which would solve the problem that I raised? For example, it would not be reasonable for the Minister by regulation to declare the occupation of truck driving a genuine qualification for the employment of a person of a particular sex, because clearly women can be truck drivers. They might operate as a pair in driving a truck from Melbourne to Perth. Similarly, it would not be reasonable to declare by regulation that the position of a telephone fixer-upper, or whatever the position is--
—Technician.

—The suggested word is 'technician'. I am sure that it is a much more significant position that technician, but that would perhaps cover it. It would not be reasonable for the Minister to declare that an occupational qualification for one sex or the other. So, the regulation-making provisions would not be a solution to the problem I raised.

talker.name: Senator RYAN
talker.role: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women)

talk.start.para: —Being male would not be a declared occupational qualification under paragraph (h). It is not the intention to overcome the whole purpose of the legislation by regulating every case that somebody thinks of as one that fulfils the occupational qualifications requirement. That is a genuine requirement. There may be jobs in which it is a genuine occupational requirement to be of one sex; for example, acting. There would be other examples. The example which the honourable senator gave would not be exempted under regulation. I draw the attention of Senator Lewis again to paragraph (f) where it is clearly stated that if the employer cannot provide separate sleeping accommodation and sanitary facilities for persons of either sex or it would not be reasonable to expect the employer to provide them, those occupations are exempted. But where it is reasonable or where there are separate accommodation and sanitary facilities for either sex, there is no ground for an exemption.

—Is the Minister aware that she just let slip the words 'where it is reasonable', which are the words which the Opposition wants to include in the provision? I am not suggesting a situation in which an employer has to provide accommodation. Is the Minister saying that this Government believes that where an employer can clearly see that there could very easily be matters of major concern, because of the close proximity of people who work together, to the marriage of either or any one of those people- notwithstanding that the problem is one which the employer is able to foresee-he will not be able to discriminate under this legislation? Is the Government saying that that is something he just has to live with?

speech.speaker: Harradine Sen B.

talk.start.para: — I just want to comment on one of the matters which have been raised. I feel that prying into people's private lives to see whether they will get pregnant is not something which employers should be entitled to do. I just raise that matter; I do not think it was suggested by one of the honourable senators who entered the debate. I acknowledge what the Minister said in response to my question about the police motor cyclist on the BMW 1000. In effect, she said that the decision by the superintendent was made because picking up the motor-bike was a relevant requirement in the circumstances of that job. I accept that. That is why I believe that the amendment put forward by the Opposition could probably be improved if it included the words 'and the less favourable treatment is not reasonably relevant in the circumstances'. That would virtually place into the legislation what the Minister has said in answer to my question.

speech.para: I go one step further. That would deal with clause 5, which deals with sex discrimination, but as I understand it we are also dealing with clause 6, which deals with discrimination on the ground of marital status. Having regard to the definition of marital status, clause 6 clearly prevents an employer from preferring a married couple to a de facto couple in all matters covered by the legislation, including matters of employment, accommodation and education except , of course, where there are subsequent exemptions. It does so because, in the words of this clause, a characteristic that appertains generally to persons having the marital status of a de facto is, by definition of clause 4, that the persons are living as husband and wife outside of marriage and, on the view of a substantial number of people within Australia, are therefore regularly engaged in fornication and adultery. Accordingly, we should not prefer a married couple to a de facto couple on the grounds that the de facto couple was regularly committing fornication and adultery and would be a source of scandal in a work situation. I refer honourable senators to the example of a country hotel. It may well be that a hotel proprietor wishes to employ a married couple to run the hotel. Under this legislation, he is prevented from doing this and also is branded as a discriminator if he does not employ a de facto couple to run the hotel.

talk.start.para: —Even if they are not as good as the married couple? He has to employ the less capable people because they are de facto. That is what you said.
—No, I did not.
—I am sorry. That is precisely what you said. That is what I am trying to clarify.
—No, I did not say that.
—Order! I ask for less direct interchange and more talking through the Chair.

—No, I did not say that at all. What I said was that he wants to employ a married couple. First, he cannot advertise for a married couple to run the hotel and, secondly, if he advertises for a couple to run the hotel and gets an application from a de facto couple whose qualifications are excellent, and he refuses to give them the job, under this legislation he will be a discriminator. That is what I am saying.

—Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. I have practised, like most people, a fair effort in trying to listen tonight but I draw your attention to Standing Order 421 and ask whether you regard this contribution as tediously repetitious.
—Order! There is no point of order. Senator Harradine is dealing with fundamental issues concerned with the legislation. He is in order.
—I am trying to give examples of what happens in many country towns throughout the length and breadth of Australia.
—No one has denied that. This is the twentieth century.

—I am talking of a number of country hotels the proprietors of which might wish to employ married couples. It might be detrimental to the business of the proprietor to employ a de facto couple to run the hotel; yet this Bill enforces the Government's view on that proprietor and forces him to employ the de facto couple. Frankly, the law should not deny a prospective employer the right to employ persons and to discriminate in favour of certain persons on the ground of what is relevant in the circumstances. I think the Minister mentioned those words 'relevant in the circumstances'. Whilst I believe that the Opposition's amendment is probably adequate, I would have picked up what the Minister said and used the words 'reasonably relevant in the circumstances' rather than 'reasonable in the circumstances'.

speech.speaker: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

talk.start.para: —Senator Ryan, the Minister, very adequately has expressed a set of words which shows a way around the proposition I put. So that I thoroughly understand will she answer yes or no whether it is an offence for a prospective employer to ask a woman whether she is married or then whether it is her intention to have a family in the immediate future with the knowledge that, if the answer is yes, the employer will not put her on because she will not be able to fulfil the term of contract which is necessary under the circumstances. I understand what the Minister said. She talked about--
—We are not on that clause.
—Yes, we are. Senator Ryan knows we are speaking to the right clause.

question.speaker: Bolkus Sen N.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 24 August 1983:

question.para: (1) Has the Minister for Resources and Energy's attention been drawn to a report in the Times of India of 7 May 1983 which stated that 300 nuclear workers have been contaminated in the Tarapur nuclear power plant near Bombay.

(2) Did the Times of India also report that because of a shortage of trained personnel, Indians with little or no knowledge of radiation are being shuttled in and out of nuclear 'hot spots' for brief periods.
(3) Do Tarapur workers continually receive radiation doses far above allowable standards.
(4) Why has the United States refused to supply India with more uranium to refuel the Tarapur reactors.

answer.speaker: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) and (2) I understand that an article in the Times of India of 9 May 1983 reported that in the operation of the Tarapur atomic power reactors (TAPS) more than 300 people had been exposed to annual radiation doses in excess of 5,000 millirems. The article also reported that TAPS management had for some years brought in skilled and unskilled workers from outside to help TAPS employees because too many TAPS employees had received exposures in excess of annual limits. The article stated that a large number of local villagers, most of them semi-literate, had been used for high risk maintenance jobs.

(3) The Times of India article stated that the average exposure of all TAPS employees in 1982 was 2,222 millirems. Radiation doses of this magnitude fall between the International Commission for Radiological Protection (ICRP) recommended annual limits of 5,000 millirems for employees designated as radiation workers and 500 millirems for other than designated employees and for members of the public. A further Times of India article on 12 May 1983 reported the then Chairman of the Indian Atomic Energy Commission as revealing that since 1969, 329 person had received radiation exposures in excess of the 5,000 millirem annual limit. In a debate in the Indian Parliament on 25 July 1983 the Minister for Science and Technology stated that ICRP recommendations provide for the basic limit of 5,000 millirems for designated radiation workers to be exceeded under special approval to meet specific work requirements. However, the ICRP recommendations note that such exposures should occur only infrequently during normal operations.

(4) The decision by the United States to refuse to continue to supply India with enriched uranium to refuel the Tarapur reactors was based on provisions of the United States Nuclear Non-Proliferation Act (NNPA) of 1978. The Act prohibits in principle the export of nuclear materials such as enriched uranium to countries which do not accept International Atomic Energy Agency safeguards on all nuclear facilities (fullscope safeguards). India does not accept fullscope safeguards. The NNPA required India to accept obligations additional to those included in the Nuclear Co-operation Agreement with the United States signed in 1963 before further enriched uranium would be supplied by the United States, namely IAEA safeguards over all of its nuclear facilities. There have been no United States approvals for fuel shipments since 1980.
