question.speaker: Jones Sen G.N.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry , upon notice, on 3 November 1983:

question.para: (1) What is the primary objective of the joint Commonwealth-State fisheries research program in Torres Strait announced in the August Budget.
How will Torres Strait Islanders benefit directly from this research program.
(3) Is the program under way and what is its expected duration.
(4) Will a report (or progressive reports) be published on the results of the research program.

answer.speaker: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Primary Industry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Under the Torres Strait Treaty both Australia and Papua New Guinea have a number of obligations regarding fisheries management. These obligations arise from a desire to:
(a) protect the traditional way of life and livelihood of the traditional inhabitants, including traditional fishing-the principal purpose of the Protected Zone (Article 10);

(b) co-operate and consult in the conservation, management and optimum utilisation of Protected Zone commercial fisheries, provided there is due protection given to traditional fisheries (Articles 20, 21);
(c) manage particular fisheries jointly if either party considers this necessary (Article 22);
(d) implement a catch-sharing arrangement for Protected Zone commercial fisheries jointly managed by the two countries (Article 23);

(e) take into account the desirability of promoting economic development in the Torres Strait area and employment opportunities for traditional inhabitants when issuing commercial fishing licences, and ensure traditional inhabitants are consulted from time to time on licensing arrangements for Protected Zone commercial fisheries (Article 26);
(f) protect and preserve the marine environment and the indigenous flora and fauna in and around the Protected Zone (Articles 13, 14).

The primary objective of the fisheries research program in Torres Strait is to collect the biological and other information needed to support management programs that will fulfil the above aims of the Treaty. Current research projects are designed to:
(1) (a) establish the extent and nature of traditional fishing by traditional inhabitants;
(b) study the biology of commercially exploited species such as tropical rock lobsters, prawns, mackerel and trochus for management and optimum utilisation of those species;
(c) study the effects of prawn trawling on other species, including those fished traditionally.
In addition, a monitoring program is to be set up to gather information to ensure continued productivity of the resources and the protection of traditional fishing activities.

(2) Torres Strait Islanders will benefit directly from this research program in a number of ways. The documentation of traditional fishing will allow for its protection, if necessary, and will provide information necessary for the conservation and sustained use of traditional resources such as dugongs and turtles, which may be under threat.

The results of research into commercial fisheries will be used for the management of Protected Zone commercial fisheries with the objective of attaining optimum utilisation and, where appropriate, the promotion of economic development of the Torres Strait area and employment opportunities for traditional inhabitants.

(3) The program is already under way. A tropical rock lobster study was initiated in 1980 and other projects commenced in 1983. The more recent projects include studies of traditional fishing, the effects of prawn trawling on non- target species, an aerial survey of tiger prawn nursery grounds and determination of the extent of the mackerel stock.

The duration of the program will depend to a large extent on the results. At present, most projects are scheduled to run to 1984 or 1985, however, funds will be sought to extend some projects if results indicate this is necessary.

(4) The results of all research projects will be published in due course, both in scientific journals and as progress reports in industry magazines such as Australian Fisheries. Scientists are currently considering holding a research seminar in late 1984 to examine the progress of research. The proceedings of this seminar would also be published.

question.speaker: Rae Sen P.E.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Trade, upon notice, on 17 November 1983:

question.para: (1) Has the Department of Trade collated in publishable form the material referred to by the Minister for Trade on 14 September 1983, when he stated that 'My own Department has also identified some 2,000 instances of non-tariff mechanisms being used by other countries'. (See answer to Questions without Notice, House of Representatives Hansard, 14 September 1983, p. 755).
(2) Will this information be made available to honourable members and senators; if so, when.
(3) When will the Department publish this material for public consumption.

answer.speaker: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

talk.start.para: —The Acting Minister for Trade has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The Department of Trade has prepared a preliminary inventory of more than 2 ,000 non-tariff measures (NTM's) used by countries which could affect trade.

The concept of NTM's embraces all types of governmental non-tariff trade actions, including procedures and regulations, without pre-judging and motivations for their application, their conformity or otherwise with domestic or international laws or their actual effect on trade.
The inventory is a consolidation of all relevant measures listed in:
(i) the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade 'Inventory of Non-Tariff Measures' put out in a series of documents prefixed by the code NTM/INV
(ii) the GATT 'Inventory of Agricultural Non-Tariff Measures' (put out in a series of documents pre- fixed by the code AG/DOC)
(iii) the USTR 'Foreign Trade Action Monitoring System' (TAMS) printout
(iv) public documents and from other sources available to the Department.

It should be noted that this inventory is broadly based and does not indicate the possible impact on trade of particular NTM's. It should also be borne in mind that since this list was prepared six months ago, it will in some respects be out of date.
The Department is currently updating its information base on NTM's and quantifying where possible, their trade effects.
(2) and (3) It is not appropriate to turn this document into a publication at this stage but I have authorised my Department to make it available on request.

answer.speaker: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

talk.start.para: —On 15 September 1983 (Hansard, page 739), Senator Watson asked me a question, without notice, concerning research in Australia into utilising hydrogen as a source of energy, and government incentives for such research.

answer.para: The 'Compendium of Australian Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Projects', published by my Department, identifies four hydrogen projects currently in progress in Australia. These are in the areas of hydrogen production using solar energy, hydrogen storage and processing, and the use of hydrogen as a vehicle fuel. Most of the funding for these projects has been provided by the Commonwealth through the national energy research, development and demonstration (NERDD) program. Between 1978 and 1982 $462,115 was committed under the program.

answer.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talk.start.para: —On 21 September 1983 (Hansard, page 859), Senator Watson asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology a question, without notice, concerning government support for high technology and referring specifically to the proposed reduction of 80 personnel within the Defence Science and Technology Organisation.

answer.para: The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

(1) The external review of the Defence Science and Technology Organisation ( DSTO) which was completed in October 1980 made a number of recommendations to redress the effects of decreasing resources. The thrust of some of these recommendations-and the Government endorses this thrust-was that there was a need to:
(a) Provide adequate operating resources for DSTO scientists and engineers; and
(b) Replace obsolete DSTO plant over a period of time.

(2) resources available to DSTO have had to be constrained in the light of overall defence priorities in a period of tightly controlled defence expenditure overall. This constraint has led to a situation where the support funds available to the DSTO scientists and engineers were falling below levels judged necessary for effective research and development activity.

(3) It was therefore decided that some reductions would be made in the manpower resources for the DSTO in exchange for increased allocations for operating costs and minor capital funds. Manning reductions of about 80 positions out of a total of about 4,500 are being made in 1983-84 by selective non-replacement of natural staff wastage. There will be no retrenchments.
(4) This will increase the effectiveness of DSTO in most areas, but as a result of the staff reductions work in some lower priority areas will be curtailed.

talk.start.para: —On 13 September 1983 (Hansard, page 590), Senator Missen asked a question concerning a report by the London-based Anti-Slavery Society for the Protection of Human Rights concerning alleged human rights abuses of the Melanesian population of Irian Jaya. In my reply I outlined the nature of the Indonesian Government's transmigration program in Irian Jaya and international efforts to protect the rights of indigenous peoples. answer.para: The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following additional information:
The Anti-Slavery Society for the Protection of Human Rights plans to publish reports on its findings in Irian Jaya within the next 12 months.

Until that report is published, the Society's statement to the United Nations Working Group on Indigenous Populations in Geneva is the most definitive account of the Society's views. A copy of the Society's statement is available from Mr Hayden's office.

It is difficult to obtain accurate figures on the number of transmigrants who have gone to Irian Jaya as target figures are often not realised. However, according to the Indonesian Department of Transmigration, 58,000 people had been transferred to the province as at the end of August 1983.
In addition to transmigrants, there are also another 100,000-160,000 unsponsored migrants in Irian Jaya.

According to a study by Professor Arndt of the Australian National University, transmigration to Irian Jaya during the Indonesian Government's current third five year development plan (1979-1984) represents around 4.3 per cent of total official transmigrants. This compares with 60.6 per cent settled in Sumatra, 20. 2 per cent in Kalimantan and 12.3 per cent in Sulawesi.

answer.speaker: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

talk.start.para: —On 29 November 1983 (Hansard, page 2903), Senator Hearn asked me a question without notice concerning discussions between my Department and the Hydro-Electric Commission on the potential for wind-generated electricity in northern Tasmania and my own plans regarding the commercial production of wind- generated electricity in Denmark.
